DIV1.P: As it is PERFORMED At the THEATRE-ROYAL in DRURY-LANE.
Written by the EDITOR of Miss SIDNEY BIDULPH.
EDINBURGH: Printed for R. FLEMING, M. DCC. LXIII.

LG.L: A Female culprit at your bar appears,
Not destitute of hope, nor free from fears.
Her utmost crimes she's ready to confess,
A simple trespass—neither more nor less;
For, truant-like, she rambled out of bounds,
And dar'd to venture on poetic grounds.
The fault is deem'd high-treason by the men,
Those lordly tyrants who usurp the pen!
Then try the vile monopoly to hide
With flattering arts, 'You, ladies, have beside
'So many ways to conquer—sure 'tis fit
'You leave to us that dangerous weapon wit!"
For women, like state criminals, they think
Should be debarr'd the use of pen and ink.
Our author, who disclaims such partial laws,
To her own sex appeals to judge her cause.
She pleads old magna charta on her side,
That British subjects by their peers be try'd.
Ladies, to you she dedicates her lays,
Assert your right to censure or to praise;
Nor doubt a sentence by such lips decreed,
Firm as the laws of Persian or of Mede;
Boldly your will in open court declare,
And let the men dispute it if they dare.
Our humble scenes no charms of art can boast,
But simple nature, and plain sense at most:
Perhaps some character—a moral too—
And what is stranger still—the story's new:
No borrow'd thoughts throughout the piece are shewn,
But what our author writes is all her own.
By no sly hint, or incident she tries
To bid on modest cheeks the blush arise:
The loosest thoughts our decent scenes suggest,
Virtue herself might harbour in her breast;
And where our harmless satire vents its spleen,
The soberest prude may laugh, without a skreen.
But not to mirth alone we claim your ear,
Some tender scenes demand the melting tear;
The comic dame, her different powers to prove,
Gives you the dear variety you love;
Sometimes assumes her graver sister's art,
Borrows her form, and tries to touch the heart,
But fancy's pictures float upon the brain,
And short-liv'd o'er the heart is passion's reign,
Till judgment stamp her sanction on the whole,
And sink th'impression deep into the soul.—

ROW.CELL: Col. MEDWAY, Son to Lord Medway,
Lady FLUTTER, Niece to Sir Anthony,

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, a Library.
DIV3.STAGE: Lord Medway reading at a Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: HOW's this, madam? pursue me into my study! my sanctuary! I thought this place, at least, was to be considered by your Lady∣ship as inviolable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I hope I don't interrupt you, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I should be glad, lady Medway, that we remember'd our respective bounds. I never intrude at your tea-table or toilet; and I desire my hours of retirement may be held as sa∣cred by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, my Lord, but indeed you have made me so exceedingly unhappy by this sudden resolution you have taken, in regard to marrying your daughter, that I can find rest no where.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
And so you are come, like the evil spirit, to take pos∣session of me, in order to make me as restless as yourself. I am really extremely obliged to your Ladyship; but you must know, ma'am, I am of so strange a disposition, that I have an absolute dislike to the being made uneasy; and therefore shall take it as a favour, if you will either, at once, chearfully acqui∣esce in what I have determined, or else go, and display your
plaintive eloquence to some one better disposed to sympathize with you than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Lord, you know your will has ever been a law to me; but I beg of you to consider the cruelty of forcing young people to marry against their inclinations.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Madam, I did not expect this idle opposition from you, especially when you know my motives to this marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Lord, you have not yet explained them to me; I can only guess at large.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You know I am harassed with debts, and I now tell you, I don't know where to raise five hundred pounds more, if it would save me from perdition; and pray, let me ask your Ladyship, do you know any one besides Sir Anthony Branville, who will take your daughter without a fortune? for I neither am, nor probably ever shall be, able to give her one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But Louisa is very young, my Lord; why need we be so precipitate? Besides, if this match between Mrs. Knight∣ly and your son should take place, it will then be in your pow∣er to provide for your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Right woman!—a hint is but just started, and you pursue, run it down, and seize it at once. I have not yet pro∣posed the thing to my son. Perhaps he may not like the lady when I do; and I presume you will think his inclinations as proper to be consulted, as those of the young lady his sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Certainly, my Lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh no doubt on't; love-matches against the world! All you ladies, in this particular, are very ready to adhere to that christian precept, of doing as you would be done by: and so I suppose, you, out of your maternal fondness, would re∣commend it to me to let Miss please herself in the choice of a husband, as her mamma did before her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: That reproach from ou, my Lord, is not kind—but I do not desire you to let her please herself in chusing one she likes, only do not force her to take one she hates.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Has she told you that she hates Sir Anthony?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Not in express words; but the repugnance she shews—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Perhaps she loves some one else.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: To tell you the truth, my Lord, I believe she does.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And she has made you the confident of her tender passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I extorted something like a confession of this sort from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And pray who may be the happy man?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Young Branville, Sir Anthony's nephew, who is now on his travels, and is expected every day home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: A forward little gipsey—This is the curse of mar∣rying early, to have our children tugging at our purse-strings, at a time when we have as quick a relish for the joys of life as they have, and ten times a better capacity for pursuing them.—Look'ee, madam, I cannot give her a shilling; Sir Antho∣ny is ready to take her as she is; and if they should have a fa∣mily, is able to provide liberally for them all. On the con∣trary, if she follows her own soft inclinations, in marrying Mr. Branville, I suppose, in three or four years, I should have the pleasure of seeing myself a grand papa to two or three pretty little beggars, who, between their mother's vanity, and their father's poverty, may happen to continue so all their lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But, my Lord, as Sir Anthony has sent his nephew a∣broad at his own expence, it looks as if he meant to do some∣thing handsome for him: besides, he is his uncle's heir in case he should die without children by marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And so you think you can keep him in a state of ce∣libacy, by refusing him your daughter—Oh fy, Lady Med∣way, I never heard you argue so weakly. Sir Anthony is not yet past the prime of life; besides, he has owned to me that it was his being discarded by Mrs. Knightly, which made him resolve, at once, in a sort of pique, to marry the first girl that fell in his way; birth and reputation being all the fortune he desired with her. A man thus circumstanced, is very little like∣ly to continue a batchelor—No, no, I'll take him in the hu∣mour, and secure him while I may.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Before it be too late, my Lord, let me once more be∣seech you to reflect on the misery of a married life, where on either side love or esteem is wanting. Have we not a glaring
instance of this in the house with us, in Sir Harry Flutter and his wife? are they not as wretched a pair as ever met in wed∣lock, perpetually quarrelling! I own, I almost repent my in∣vitation to them, and wish them fairly back again in the coun∣try.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That must not be. (Aside.) You have made a very unlucky choice in your example, ma'am; a foolish boy, and a giddy girl, that know not either of them what they would be at. He married the wife his mother chose for him, to get rid of his tutor; and she took the husband her wife father pro∣vided for her, to escape from a boarding school. What can be expected from two such simpletons? He, proud of the au∣thority of a husband, exercises it from the same principle, and with pretty much the same capacity, that children shew with regard to poor little animals that are in their power, in teaz∣ing and controlling them; and this he thinks makes him look manly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: So I imagine, for I have heard him say, he does no more than other husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: She, on the other hand, fancies the prerogatives of a wife consist in contradicting and opposing him; and this, I presume, she thinks is doing like other wives: but my life for it, when they know a little more of the world, they will be very happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Never in each other, I am afraid, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And pray, ma'am, let me ask you, what mighty feli∣city have you enjoyed, in being married to the man of your choice?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: That is a strange question, my Lord! I never com∣plained of my lot; but if I have not been completely happy, it is not owing to any fault of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: It may be mine for ought I know—but I only mention it, to shew you that love is not such an almighty deity, as to confer happiness without certain ingredients besides, that I could name.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Lord, where it is reciprocal, there wants not much besides.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Be sure you preach that wise doctrine to your daugh∣ter; it will become your prudence, and no doubt will be ex∣tremely agreeable to her pretty romantic notions—But pr'ythee let us have done with the subject at once. One cir∣cumstance more, however, I shall acquaint you with; if the marriage between Medway and this lady should be accom∣plished, I have other purposes to appropriate her fortune to, than buying a husband for your daughter—But this is only in speculation—the thing may never happen—for nothing but the last extremity should compel me to urge my son against his inclination. In regard to Louisa, in two words, I will be obeyed: do me the favour to tell her as much. I shall see her presently, and expect such an answer from her, as her du∣ty shall dictate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Lord, it is an unpleasing task you have assign'd me, but I will obey you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That you have always done, so much praise I will allow you—but I am out of humour with every thing. If this boy should dislike the match. I am un∣done at once—'Sdeath what a thing it is to have poverty star∣ing a man in the face, and no way to keep the horrid spectre from laying hold on you!—No way but one; it all depends on Medway's filial duty—A thousand vexations crowd up∣on me together—'Tis a pretty time for a man to think of in∣triguing! and yet the blooming beauty of that little madcap, with all her childishness about her, has caught such hold on me, that I must have her—Oh with what alacrity now could I pursue the chace, if my thoughts were a little more disen∣gaged!—She has been complaining to my wife of her hus∣band's ill usage of her; and he, I suppose, will come to me presently, to take a lesson, as he calls it, to enable him to use her worse—he shan't want my assistance—and here he comes to receive it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh my dear Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why, you seem out of breath, Sir Harry, what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Upon my soul, my Lord, I have been so stunn'd this morning, with the din of conjugal interrogatories, that I am quite bated—do, let me lounge a little on this couch of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What, I suppose you were playing the rogue last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: No faith, only at the tavern. I was at home before three o'clock, and yet my wife was such an unreason∣able little devil, as to ask me forty questions about my stay∣ing out so late.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: It's the way of them all—but I hope you are too well acquainted with your own prerogative, to give her any satisfaction on those accounts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Satisfaction! ho catch me at that, and gibbet me—no, no—But pray now, my Lord, how would you be∣have on such an occasion? for I should be very glad to find that my conduct squared with yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why—not roughly—you know that is not my way—it is not manly; besides, it would at once provoke, and justify your wife in her resentment.—But there is a sort of sneering, ironical treatment, that I never knew fail of nettling a woman to the quick; and the best of it is, the thing won't bear repetition; for let them deliver your very words, without the tone and air accompanying them, and there shall not ap∣pear the least harm in them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Ay that, that's the secret I want to come at; that's the true art of tormenting, and what of all the talents your Lordship possesses, I envy you for the most—Heavens, how I have seen my Lady swell, and tears start into her eyes, when, devil take me if I thought you were not in perfect good humour all the while—Now, I am rather petulant, flash, flash, flash as quick as lightning, till I put my self into a confound∣ed passion, when I only meant to vex her—Tho' I think I was rather temperate too, this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: How was it, let's hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P:
Why, I came home at three o'clock, as I told you, a little tipsy too, by the by; but what was that to her,
you know, for I am always good humoured in my cups? To bed I crept, as softly as a mouse, for I had no more thought of quarrelling with her then, than I have now with your Lord∣ship—La, says she, with a great heavy sigh, it is a sad thing that one must be disturbed in this manner; and on she went, mutter, mutter, mutter, for a quarter of an hour; I all the while lying as quiet as a lamb, without making her a word of answer; at last, quite tired of her perpetual buzzing in my ear, Pr'ythee be quiet, Mrs. Wasp, says I, and let me sleep (I was not thoroughly awake when I spoke.) Do so, Mr. Drone, grumbled she, and gave a great flounce. I said no more, for in two minutes I was as fast as a top. Just now, when I came down to breakfast, she was seated at the tea∣table all alone, and looked so neat, and so cool, and so pret∣ty, that e'gad, not thinking of what had passed, I was going to give her a kiss; when up she toss'd her demore little face, You were a pretty fellow, last night, Sir Harry. says she: So I am every night, I hope, ma'am, says I, making her a low bow. Was not that something in your manner, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh very well, very well—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Pray where were you till that unconscionable hour, says she? At the tavern drinking, says I, very civilly. And who was with you, Sir? Oh, thought I, I'll match you for your enquiries; I nam'd your Lordship, and half a dozen more wild fellows, (whom, by the way, I had not so much as seen) and two or three girls of the town, added I, whistling, and looking another way—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That was rather a little, though but a little, too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P:
Down she slap'd her cup and saucer; If this be the case, Sir Harry, (half sobbing) I shall desire a separate bed. That's as I please, madam, sticking my hand in my side, and looking her full in the face. No, it shall be as I please, sir—it shan't, madam; it shall, sir; and it shan't, and it shall, and it shall, and it shan't, was bandied backwards and forwards till we were both out of breath with passion. At last she said something to provoke me, I don't know what it
was, but I answered her a little tartly. You would not have said it, I believe—I'd give the world for your command of temper—but it slip'd out faith—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Why, I said (for she vexed me cursedly) I said—faith I think I—as good as told her, she ly'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh sy!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: She burst out a crying, I kick'd down the tea∣table, and away I scampered up to your Lordship, to receive advice and consolation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why really, Sir Harry, I pity you; to be ty'd to such a little termagant is the devil; but 'tis the fortune of wedlock. One thing I have always observed; the more a husband submits, the more a wise tyrannizes. 'Twas my own case at first; but I was soon obliged to alter my course, and by exerting myself a little, I brought Lady Medway to be as well-behaved, I think, as any woman of quality in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: So she is upon my word, my Lord; I'd change with you with all my heart, if my Lady were a little younger. Duce take me but I wish we were like the Spartans; I assure you, if their laws were in force here, my wife should be at your service, and I dare say I should be as welcome to yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh undoubtedly, Sir Harry!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: The women would like it vastly—your wife and mine I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: How do you know that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Why I know mine doesn't care sixpence for me, and I suppose it may be pretty much the same with yours, and with all of them for that matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That doesn't follow—but how do you intend to act with regard to Lady Flutter? I suppose this little breach will be made up like all the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Not by me, I assure you, my Lord; I don't in∣tend to speak to her to-day; and when I do, she shall ask my pardon before I forgive her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
Boh, that's children's play, fall out, and then pray, pray, kiss and be friends. No, Sir Harry, if you would shew
yourself a man, and a husband, let her see that you despise her little girlish petulance, by taking no farther notice of it. Now, were I in your case, I'd behave just as if nothing at all had happened. If she pouts, smile; and ask her how she likes your new sword-knot, or the point in your ruffles, or any o∣ther idle question. You know she must give you an answer. If it be a peevish one, laugh in her face, take up your hat, and wish her a good morning; if on the contrary, she speaks with good humour, seem not to hear her, but walk about the room, repeating verses. Then, as if you had not observed her before, Did you speak to me, Lady Flutter? but without wait∣ing for her reply, slide out of the room, humming a tune—Now all this, you see, were she to relate it, will not have the appearance of ill treatment; and yet my life for yours, it humbles her more than all the blustering airs you could put on.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: I am sure you are right, my Lord. The case is plain; but the difficulty is in executing the thing properly, I am so warm in my temper. Oh what would I give for your glorious cool sneer of contempt!—I'll try for it positively; and e'gad I'll now go to her and make the experiment; and so, my Lord, adieu for the present, and thanks for this lesson.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir Harry! do you dine at home to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: I don't know how that may be till I have re∣connoitred; your Lordship, I know, does not—and I hate to dine alone with the women.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, I shall certainly be at home soon after dinner; for I shall long to know on what terms you and my Lady may be by that time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh heaven knows—we may be at cuffs by that time, perhaps; but I shall be in the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: If he follows my advice, I think she must hate him heartily—and then I step in as her comforter—But I have other business to mind at present—so many projects on foot without a certainty of accomplishing one of them—Z—ns, if I had not the firmness of a Stoic, I should beat my own brains out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My dear, it afflicts me as much as it does you; but you know your papa is absolute: I wish, therefore, you would endeavour to reconcile yourself to Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Indeed, madam, it is impossible! If my heart were ever so much at liberty, it never could endure that forbidding man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But, child, you are too much governed by fancy;—tho' he is not quite in the bloom of youth, yet is hefar from being disagreeable. What is it you so much dislike in him?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Dear madam! sure the pomp and strange turn of his phrases, and the solemnity of his manner, is almost ridicu∣lous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: He is rather formal, I allow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: And then his notions of love so extravagant, his ad∣dress so romantic, nothing but flames and rapture in his mouth, and, according to my brother's account of him, he has no more real warmth than a marble statue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: You find he lov'd Mrs. Knightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: His peculiarities diverted her, madam, and she in∣dulged him in them—I am told he used to sigh at her feet for half a day, and if he committed the smallest fault, she would impose a penance on him, which Sir Anthony always receiv∣ed as a mark of favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I am sorry, my dear, it is not more agreeable to you; for I am commissioned to tell you, positively, you must accept of him for a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: But, madam, he has never spoken a word to me on the subject—I have seen him but a few times, and—in short, I can't bear him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Shall I tell your papa what you say? he, no doubt, will be perfectly satisfied with this determination.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P:
Dear madam! sure you will not. Save me from my papa's anger, you know I dare not open my heart to him. You (except in your maternal tenderness) are more like a com∣panion
to me than a parent. The authority of the mother is melted down in the kindness of the friend; my papa's severity had else been insupportable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Louisa, you are not to give so harsh a name to your father's sollicitude for your happiness. He is not to be shaken in his resolution. I have already exerted my utmost influence over him, and that I am sorry to say, is less, much less, than it ought to be.—Hist!—I hear your father's voice below; he is coming up to you. I beg, my dear, you will let him see by your obedience, that my interposition has had its proper ef∣fect. I'll give you the opportunity to talk to him alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Dear madam, don't leave me—my papa is so stern.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I go to avoid ungrateful appeals from him. Consent with a good grace, Louisa, for 'tis certain you have no choice left.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Heavens, what will become of me!
SP.STAGE: Lord Medway enters, stops at the Door, and looks at her, she not observing him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.L: On every hill, in every grove,
Along the margin of each stream,
Dear conscious scenes of former love—
I mourn, and Damon is my theme.
SP.P: What is your pretty tender heart ruminating upon? your Da∣mon, I suppose—were not you thinking of Mr. Branville?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: No, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I believe you don't tell truth, my Lady—look up, girl—Ah Louisa, Louisa, that conscious blush! but 'tis well you have the grace to be ashamed.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My Lord, if I do blush, I am not conscious of any cause, unless the fear of offending you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Pretty innocent!—all obedience too, I warrant. I hate hypocrisy from my very soul; you know that you are a rebel in the bottom of your heart. Speak honestly now, would not you run away with Branville this very night, if it were in your power?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My Lord, I—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: My Lord, I—I—, speak out, Mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: If I had your permission, my Lord, I own I should be—inclined to prefer him to—any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord
SP.P: Thou prevaricating monkey—dissemblers too from the very egg. And without my permission, Miss: what an∣swer does your modesty and filial piety suggest to that?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: That without it, I will never marry any one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I don't believe one syllable of that;—but I take you at your word; and now I tell you that you never shall have it to marry him—How does your love-sick heart re∣lish that?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My Lord, I am resign'd to your pleasure.
SP.STAGE: [She curtsies and offers to go, he bows, and lets her walk to the Door.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Now, ma'am—walk back if you please—for I have not done with you yet. [She comes back.]—Whither were you swimming with that sweet languishing air, like an Arcadian princess?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I was going to my chamber, my Lord, if you had not forbid it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Forbid! fy, what an ungenteel word to use towards a heroine in romance! There are some surly fathers, indeed, who take those liberties with their children; but I, who know breeding better, only intreat; and therefore, ma'am, beg the favour of your company a little longer; if a mind dignified by the noble passion of love, can condescend to the admoniti∣ons of a parent—What does the fool hang her head for? Sit down there—What, you are going to faint, I hope—Oh I d—y—e! I ex-pire—Branville take my last adieu—Here, Betty, some hartshorn for the despairing nymph, quick∣ly—your lady is dying for love.—So, so, so, the sluice is let out at last.—
So lilies look surcharg'd with morning dew!
You really look very pretty when you cry, Louisa, I had a mind to see how it would become you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, you are too hard upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: How now, mistress! how dare you speak thus? What do you call a hardship? Love makes some timorous animals bold, they say; it makes women so with a vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My Lord, I beg your permission to withdraw.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Stay where you are, madam.—When I condescend to talk with you, methinks you ought to know, 'tis your duty to attend to what I have to say. You know my mind already in regard to young Branville.—Ay, sigh on—fy, fy, do those glowing aspirations become a young lady educated as you have been? Your mother, I am sure, has always set you a good example. I was no pattern for you to follow.—But observe what I say; I forbid you to think, but even to think, of Branville. That is the first, and perhaps the hardest part of my command. The next is, that you resolve immediately to accept of Sir Anthony for your husband. And now, Miss, you may, if you please, retire to your chamber, and, in plain∣tive strains, either in verse or prose, bemoan your hard fate; and be sure you complain to your waiting-woman what a ty∣rant you have to your father.—Go, get you gone.
This is the plague of having daughters; no sooner out of their leading-strings than in love, forsooth.
Oh George, I am glad you are come; that foolish girl has ruffled me so, I want relief from my own thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I met my sister in tears—I hope, my Lord, she has done nothing to disoblige you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh a mere trifle—only confessed a passion for a fellow not worth sixpence, but what depends on the caprice of a relation, and, like a prudent as well as dutiful child, has shewn a thorough dislike of her father's choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, she will consider better of it; I am sure my sister would willingly obey you in every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
To what purpose is a father's sollicitude for the wel∣fare of his children, if a perverse silly girl will counter-act all his projects?—You, Medway, have ever shewn yourself an
affectionate, as well as an obedient son, to a parent who con∣fesses himself, with regard to you, not one of the most provi∣dent—I wish I could make you amends.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, the tenderness you have always shewn me, deserved every return I could make you.—I wish for no o∣ther amends but to see you easy in your mind and in your cir∣cumstances.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That's well said! but I expected as much from you. Suppose, now, that it were in your power to make me easy in both, and at the same time effectually to serve yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I wish it were, my Lord, you should see my readiness to embrace the opportunity—But I am afraid there is no∣thing now in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh you are mistaken, there are ways and means to retrieve all; and it was on this subject I wanted to talk with you—There is a certain lady of fortune, son—What! droop at the very mention of her? that's an ill omen.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I doubt my fortune never can be mended by those means.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: No! Suppose the widow Knightly, with a real estate of three thousand a year, and a personal one of fifty thousand pounds, should have taken a fancy to you, would not that be a means?—You blush; perhaps you are already acquainted with the lady's passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I am glad to see you so pleasant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am serious, I assure you—Why, is there any thing so extraordinary in a woman's falling in love with a handsome young fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, if the Lady has really done me that honour, 'tis more than I deserve; for I never made the least advances.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Well; but how do you like her?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: She is genteel, I think—I really never examined her features.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That's strange! Why, you visit her sometimes I find.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I go to her house, my Lord; but 'tis her younger si∣ster whom I visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Humph—What sort of a damsel is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: A most angelic creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Ay! then it seems you have examined her features?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I have known her long. Miss Richly, who as well as her sister was born abroad, was sent hither some years since for her education, and I became acquainted with her in the house of a friend of mine with whom she lived. Mrs. Knightly, who had married an English merchant, was then settled at Lisbon, and knew but little of her sister, till lately; when, having lost her husband, she came to England, and took the young Lady under her own care.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: So! I perceive you know their history.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I do, my Lord. Poor Miss Richly's part of it is a me∣lancholy one; for her father was so partial to his eldest daugh∣ter, that he left her by much the greatest portion of his estate; and what the youngest had to her share, she had the misfor∣tune to lose, by the breaking of a merchant, in whose hands her money lay.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You are better informed than I am, I find—Well, but what do you think of Mrs. Knightly?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Think, my Lord! I really don't know what to think. The Lady is very deserving, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But! oh those damned Buts! Am I to be butted by you all, one after the other? There's your mother first, to be sure she is very ready to acquiesce in every thing that I approve, but she thinks it hard a young creature should have any force put on her inclinations, though it be for her own good—Then Miss Louisa—she is all obedience and submission—but, alas! she has given away her heart already—And you, you too are perfectly disposed to oblige me; but you will chuse for yourself, I presume, notwithstanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P:
My Lord, you really distress me, by entertaining the least doubt of that reverence I ever have born towards you, and ever will bear; but, in a case like this (pardon me, my Lord,) I cannot at once give up all that I have now left, or can claim a right in the disposal of, my honour and my love—I own I love Miss Richly, have loved her long; and if virtue, beauty, and unaffected innocence, deserve a heart, my Lord,
she has a claim to mine, and is, I confess, entire mistress of it; yet I wish the evil (since it is one) had stopped there—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But what?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, she loves me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am sorry for it—Oh son, son, a pretty face will not redeem our acres.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I never till now lamented her want of fortune, which I knew indeed from the beginning; but still hoped that I might one day be in a condition to support her, as her own merit and my rank required. I even flattered myself that I should obtain your consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What! to marry a beggar, Medway?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I beg, my Lord, you will not use so harsh a word. She is worthy of higher, much higher dignity, than ever I could raise her to—What is a title, my Lord, stripped as I am of every thing besides?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That reproach is ungenerous, Medway; but I have deserved it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Forgive me, my Lord; I meant it not as such.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: If you had, I could forgive it—but we will say no more on the subject. I will not urge you on so tender a point.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Answer me but one question: Are you under a pro∣mise to marry Miss Richly?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: No, my Lord, her generosity would not suffer her to let me bind myself by any other tie than that of inclination, as I insisted on her being free.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That's well—Then I do not see how your honour is so much concerned; and as for your love, when I was of your age, Medway, I had so many loves, that it was hard to tell which of them had the best claim.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, you were so kind as to promise you would in∣sist no farther on the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Well, well, I have done—I'll detain you no long∣er. Some business calls me out at present; I shall see you in the evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I'll attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: The firmness of this young man's virtue awes me. I know in point of interest, with regard to himself at least, it will be impossible to prevail on him to think of this marriage—and the obligations he has already laid me under, will not suf∣fer me to make, on my own account, so severe a trial of the tenderness and generosity of his heart—Let it go; I'll think no more of it.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, A Dressing-room.
DIV3.STAGE: Sir Harry Flutter, as just dressed. A servant attending.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: IS your Lady come in, can you tell?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My Lady did not go out at all, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Not at all! Why I understood she dined abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: No, Sir, I believe she only ordered Mrs. Betty to say so for an excuse, because she had no mind to come down to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Was that all?—Then do you step to her, and tell her I desire to speak with her—on very particular business tell her. [Exit Servant.] Now to put my lesson in practice—If I can but hit on the manner—I'll pretend not to see her at first—But if she should not come now—'egad, that would disconcert the whole plan—Yes, faith, here she is; her curiosity, nothing else I am sure, has brought her.
SP.STAGE: Enter Lady Flutter, with knotting in her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What do you want with me, Sir Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: I want with you, Lady Flutter! I never want∣ed any thing with you in my life, that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Why, didn't you send for me this minute, and say you had particular business? I should not have been so ready to come else, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: 'Egad, I believe I am wrong at set∣ting out; it should have all been done as if by chance. What shall I say to her now! How do you like this suit of cloaths, my dear? Don't you think it very elegant?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Was that all the business you had with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Ma'am, I insist on your not going till you answer my question; just how you please now, civilly or uncivilly; I am prepared for either, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: And so, Sir Harry, I suppose you think, with those airs, to carry off your behaviour to me this morn∣ing, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.L: Ye gods, ye gave to me a wife,
Out of your grace and favour—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: But I can tell you, Sir, I won't bear such treatment, to be drawn off and on like your glove.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Are you speaking to me, Ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: To whom else should I speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: I protest I did not know you were in the room, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh ridiculous affectation—Child! I'll assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh now it begins to work, if I can but keep cool.
SP.L: T' obey your will, at any time
I am ready to resign her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Absurd!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: To resign her, to re∣sign her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Stupid!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Ay, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Ay, indeed, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Retire to your chamber, Madam, directly, in∣stantly; and let me inform you, once for all, that you are not to take the liberty of coming into my dressing-room—A man's serious hours are not to be broke in upon by female impertinence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: A man's! ha, ha, ha, ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Those flippant airs don't become you in the least, ma'am; but I don't think a silly girl worth my serious resent∣ment—Retire with your trumpery work—I chuse to be alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Then I'll stay to vex you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Then, ma'am, I must teach you the obedience that is due to the commands of a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: A husband! Oh gracious, defend me from such a husband—A battledore and shittlecock would be fit∣ter for you than a wife, I fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: And let me tell your pertness, a doll would be properer for you than a husband—there's for you, Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: You'll be a boy all your life, Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: And you'll be a fool all your life, Lady Snap.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I shall be the fitter company for you then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Tchou, tchou, tchou.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: You are vastly polite, Sir—Did you ever see Lord Medway behave thus to his lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: And did you ever see Lady Medway behave thus to her lord, if you go to that? Rat me but a man had better be a galley-slave, than married to a simpleton that ought to be sewing her sampler.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: And I'll swear a woman had better be a bal∣lad-singer, than joined to a Jack-a-dandy, that ought to have a satchel at his back.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Devil take me but I have a good mind to break every bit of the china you bought this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Do, do, do, and make taws of them to play with.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: A provoking, impertinent little—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: How dare you call me names, Sir? I won't be called names, I'll tell my papa of this, so I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Pretty baby, laugh and cry—
For shame, wipe your eyes, don't let him see you thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I don't care who sees me; I'll bear it no longer. I will write to my papa to send for me—I'll go to my uncle Branville's this very night.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Lady Flutter! I am sorry to see you in tears, ma∣dam, I did not know you had been at home—Sir Harry, I ask your pardon, perhaps I intrude—no afflicting news, I hope

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: News! no, no, there is no thing new in the case I assure you, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then, Sir Harry, I am afraid you are in fault here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, he is always in fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: If your Lordship will take her word for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I should be glad to mediate between you, but I really don't know how, unless I were inform'd of your cause of quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: I'll tell you, my Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: No, I'll tell him, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Lookye there now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: He sent for me, my Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Not I, indeed, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I say you did, Sir Harry, on purpose to teaze me, and talk nonsense to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh fy, Sir Harry, could you find no better entertain∣ment for your lady, than talking nonsense?—This is a sad account.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Faith, my Lord, a man must unbend sometimes, and indulge in a little foolery—Life would be tedious else.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: And there he went on, repeating silly verses, to shew he wanted to get rid of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Mere raillery, my Lord; but she does not un∣derstand it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I should not have minded that so much nei∣ther, for I could be even with him in his gibing airs, if he had not at last call'd me names, downright abusive names, my Lord: but I'll put an end to it at once.
SP.STAGE: [She goes to the glass drying her eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: All wrong—all wrong—was this the advice I gave you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: My Lord, you can't imagine how provoking she was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I dare say, my papa will be very ready to take me home again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: This must not be; yet don't you condescend to de∣sire her stay, I'll try to persuade her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Ough she's a vixen!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I'll establish your empire, I'll engage, if you will give me the opportunity of talking with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Faith I wish you would, for I am almost tir'd of the struggle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Are my chairmen in the way?

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: I'll see, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: If they are, order them to get ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Going a visiting so soon, Lady Flutter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Only to my uncle Branville's, my Lord; it is proper to acquaint him with my design.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Make some excuse quickly to leave us, or all will be over.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: I will—you shall see—Bless me! Well, I am sure-ly the most thoughtless fellow breathing. [Sir Har∣ry takes out his pocket-book, and turns over the leaves.] My Lord, can you forgive my rudeness now, if I run away from you? I must shew you the nature of my engagement tho', and that, I hope, will be some apology—Wednesday, half an hour after five—you see—it's almost that already.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Humph!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Perhaps I mayn't stay long—I am very sorry to leave your Lordship alone tho'; but you'll forgive me.
SP.STAGE: [Exit Sir Harry without looking at Lady Flutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Leave me alone! 'Twere well if you were going to half as good company as that in which you leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What does your Lordship say?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Nothing, ma'am, but that I can excuse Sir Harry's going, as he leaves me in such good company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh my Lord, I am nobody in Sir Harry's opinion; but indeed, at present, I should be but a very dull companion to any me; so I am sure your Lordship will ex∣cuse me if I take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: A quarter of an hour, I hope, ma'am, will not break in too much upon your time.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My master is gone out in your chair, madam; he said you might take the chariot; will your Ladyship please to have it ordered?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Gone out in my chair! See there my Lord! did you ever know the like? I won't have the chariot—call me a hackney chair. [Exit Servant.] Pray, my Lord, where is he gone? I saw he shewed you his memorandum.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Gone! on business, I think, of some kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Business! I don't know of any business that he has; I am sure it is some other engagement.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh—what am I thinking of? 'tis to the play.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: The play! he could not have been in such a hurry for that, 'tis too early.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: He was to go with a party, and to call on some peo∣ple by the way; that was the case.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I don't much care; but I am sure that was not the thing neither; for I heard you say, it were well if he were going to half as good company, as that in which he left you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And that I should certainly say, ma'am, let him be going to whom he would. But Sir Harry has a deprav'd taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I don't doubt but he is going to some of his tavern-ladies. With all my heart; I don't love him well e∣nough to be jealous of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I wish you did, for that would help on my work. [Aside.] Why, indeed, my dear Lady Flutter, I can't say that Sir Harry is quite so deserving of you, as I could wish he were. But he is a mere boy, and can't be supposed to be so sensible of your merit, as those are, who have had a little more experience in the sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I shan't be long with him, that's one comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But, my dear ma'am, consider how that will appear in the eyes of the world. Here you are but a little while mar∣ried, what must people think of a separation? Your good un∣derstanding is unquestioned, your personal accomplishments admired by all who know you; the blame then must all fall on poor Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: And so let it for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: He deserves it, I confess; but, ma'am, give me leave to reason with you a little now; for I know you are a woman of sense, and capable of reasoning. Don't you think a leetle stroke of censure may possibly glance on you, for not endea∣vouring to bear, for a while longer at least, with his indiscre∣tion; for every body knows that your prudence is much su∣perior to his, and therefore more will be expected from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: My Lord, you compliment now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Upon my life I don't. I am sure I have said it a thousand times, that I don't know a woman of fashion in town (a handsome one I mean, you are to take that into the account too) with half your talents.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Upon my word I am serious; and, between ourselves, Sir Harry is thought to be but of very moderate parts, and that it was almost a sacrifice to marry you to him- But I would not say this for the world to any one but you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: That is very good of you, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Your discretion, I am sure, will make a proper use of the hint. There are great allowances to be made for a raw young fellow, who, like some vain and ignorant virtuoso, is possessed of a rarity, of which he neither understands the na∣ture, nor knows the value. Oh, Lady Flutter, a beautiful and accomplished woman is a gem fit only for the cabinet of a man of sense and taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Madam, the chair is ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Let it wait a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Another sip of that sweet cordial flattery, and all the rougher passions will subside.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What were you saying, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I believe I was saying, or at least I was thinking, that you are—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What, now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: A charming woman—taking you all together—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Poh! fiddle, faddle—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Indeed you are!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Well, that is nothing to the purpose—What would you advise me to do with this foolish boy; for I would not have my discretion called in question neither? I am sure if he had but the sense to talk to me as you have done, he might do just what he pleased with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Amiable creature!—Well, whatever you do, don't think of parting from him, for that would only be making mirth for all the spiteful old maids in town; who have already prophesied, that miss and master would quarrel before a month was at an end, and each run home crying to their seve∣ral mama's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Do the malicious creatures say so! Well, I'll disappoint them in that—But what can I do, my Lord, he is so intolerably conceited and pert.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
Oh don't mind him, and it will wear off by degrees! But, my dear Lady Flutter, are there not other pleasures with
which a fine woman could make herself amends, for the ill hu∣mour of her husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Not that I know of, my Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I could name you some, if you would give me leave—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: You have my leave, indeed, my Lord—My stars, what a charming thing good sense and good nature is! Your conversation has, I don't know how, soothed me so, that, though I am not happy, yet I don't find myself so much out of temper as I was a while ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh that Sir Harry and I could change situations, then would the loveliest woman in England be the happiest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Lard! my Lord, what's that for?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir Anthony Branville, madam, come to wait on your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh I am glad of that—shew him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: So am not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: You know, my Lord, it will save me the trou∣ble of going to his house this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Let me beg of you, my dear Lady Flutter, not to mention to your uncle any thing that has passed between you and Sir Harry. I'll give you many good reasons for it ano∣ther time. Have I so much influence over you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Well, my Lord, to oblige you, I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sweet condescending creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: But you must tell me what you promised.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Not now, my dear ma'am—Some other opportuni∣ty I will tell you such things—
SP.STAGE: [He bows very low to both, without speaking.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Uncle, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P:
My Lord (without a compliment) I esteem
myself extremely happy, in the agreeable hope, that I now see your Lordship in perfect health.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I thank you, good Sir Anthony, pretty well. (Heavens! what a circumlocution, to ask a man how he does!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: And you, niece, I assure you, have a very pro∣per proportion (as undoubtedly your merit claims) of my un∣feigned esteem and good wishes; as likeways hath my worthy nephew, Sir Harry; whom I should have been proud to have found in this good company, and deem both myself and him unfortunate in his being absent from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Sir Harry does'nt think so, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Hush—hush.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: What does my niece Flutter say?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Nothing, uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Pardon me; I apprehen ded you had uttered some∣thing. Well, my Lord, I am next to enquire (though, to say the truth, I ought, in point of good breeding, to have done it first;) I am next, I say, to enquire how your excellent Lady does, and the fair young Lady your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Both at your service, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: May I presume to ask the christian name of the young Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I would not have Lady Medway hear you make so emphatical a distinction, Sir Anthony; ladies you know are always young—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: 'Tis a privilege I know they claim, my Lord, and I hope you don't think me capable of such barbarism as to dis∣pute it with them; but at the same time I imagine 'tis not possible in nature, but that the mother must be rather older than her daughter—You'll excuse my pleasantry

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh surely, as the ladies are n't by—But why do you enquire my daughter's name, Sir Anthony?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Why, my Lord, there is a pretty familiar tender∣ness in sometimes using the christian name, that is truly de∣lightful to a lover; for such, my Lord, with all due deference to the Lady's high deserts, I wish myself to be considered.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh Lord, Oh Lord, my uncle Miss Medway's lover! I shall burst if I stay—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Louisa, Sir Anthony, is her christian name, which you are at liberty to use with as much familiar tenderness as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, I have a most lively sense of the very great honour your Lordship does me; and I can assure you my heart, [sight] if I can with certainty venture to pronounce about any thing which is in its own nature so uncertain—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh now he has got into his parenthesis—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My heart, I say, is endeavouring to reassume that liberty, of which it has so long been deprived, for no other purpose, than that of offering itself a willing captive again to the fair Louisa's charms.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Very well, uncle; I see this visit was not all intended for me; I find you have something to say to my Lord, so I won't interrupt you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: No, no, no, niece Flutter; upon my reputation, this visit was meant wholly for you, as I could not possibly di∣vine that I should have found his Lordship with you; to whom I intended to have paid my respects separately and apart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Lady Flutter! I ask a thousand pardons—We turn you out of your apartment—Sir Anthony, will you do me the favour to step into my study?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: No, no, indeed you shan't stir; I'll go and see what the ladies are doing; I fancy they think I am lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, I assure you I should think myself very happy in an alliance with a gentleman of your worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, you do me honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I have mentioned you to my daughter—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Mentioned me, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Wou'dn't you have had it so, Sir Anthony?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, the profound respect I have for your Lordship makes me unwilling to animadvert on such proceed∣ings, as you in your wisdom (which I take to be very great) have thought expedient; but I am a man, my Lord, who love method.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, I imagined it would have been agree∣able to you, or it should have been very far—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Conceive me right, Lord Medway; 'tis perfectly agreeable to me, and consonant to my wishes, to be looked on with a favourable eye by the virtuous young Lady your daugh∣ter; but, my Lord, to tell you sincerely (and sincerity, my Lord, I hold to be a virtue) my heart is at present in a fluctuat∣ing state.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am sorry then, Sir, that the thing has been menti∣oned at all. I understood you were determined. (What can the blockhead mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Good my Lord, your patience: I am determined; that is to say, my will is determined; but the will and the heart, your Lordship knows, are two different things.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, I should be glad we understood each o∣ther at once. I apprehended Mrs. Knightly's ill usage of you had made you give up all thoughts of her; and as you seem∣ed determined to marry, and declared yourself an admirer of my daughter, who I must say (the article of fortune excepted) is, I think, as unobjectionable a wife as you could chuse—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Undoubtedly, my Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I was willing to give my consent, and thought you appeared as ready to embrace it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: True, my Lord; and so I do still, most cordially.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why then, Sir, what is your determination? For a young woman of family and reputation must not be trifled with.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, I believe trifling is a fault which was never yet attributed to Sir Anthony Branville—My Lord, I am above the imputation—and your Lordship would do well to remember that I have the misfortune to be of a warm, not to say of an impetuous disposition.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir, I don't mean to provoke your wrath.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P:
You are the father of my mistress, my Lord—that thought restrains my fury—But this woman (Mrs. Knightly I mean, for a woman I find she is, though I once thought her an angel;) she, I say, has not yet dismissed me in
form; and till that is done, I think myself bound in honour, not to make a tender of my heart, or hand, to any Lady what∣soever.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, Sir Anthony, I find you have still a hankering af∣ter the widow, and only want an opportunity to endeavour at getting into her good graces again—You would fain see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: By no means, my Lord; not for the world! for, as I told your Lordship, I would not trust my heart with such an interview—No, no, I know the witchcraft of her beauty too well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: How do you mean to disengage yourself then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My design is to indite an epistle to her, and to request that she will under her hand, in full and explicit terms, give me an absolute and final release from all the vows I have made her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I think you are perfectly right, Sir Anthony, and act agreeably to the dictates of true honour—(I won't lose the fool if I can help it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I would sain do so, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I dare say you will get a full and free discharge from your sovereign Lady and Mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: 'Tis to be so presumed, my Lord—but as for seeing her, 'twere safer, my Lord, to encounter a basilisk, I assure you.
SP.STAGE: Mrs. Knightly rushes in a Servant attending her to the door. Sir Anthony starts, and draws back.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: My Lord, I beg your pardon; your ser∣vant told me Lady Flutter was here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am glad he made the mistake, Madam, as it has given me the honour of seeing you. Go tell your Lady—She was here but this minute—(This is unlucky.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P:
I am quite ashamed of this, my Lord; I just came to prattle half an hour with Lady Flutter, and to try if I could tempt her to the opera, and here I have broke in upon you so unawares—Bless me, Sir Anthony! is it you? I declare I did not see you? Why, you barbarian, where
have you been for this month past? My Lord, do you know that Sir Anthony is a lover of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: That Sir Anthony was a lover of yours, Ma∣dam, he has but too fatally experienced.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: And a'n't you so still, you inconstant toad?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Take my advice, and make your retreat as fast as you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Impossible, my Lord; the magic of her eyes renders me immoveable—but I'll try.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: What, I suppose my Lord is your confidant; you see I have made him mine too.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: The ladies are all gone out together, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Did your Lady leave word what time she would be at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: No, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh once they are on the wing, there is no knowing when they will return—I wish she would go. [Aside.] Will you allow me the honour of gallanting you to the opera, ma'am? I dare say Sir Anthony, on such an occasion, will excuse my leaving him—'Tis almost the time I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh dear, my Lord! too soon by [looking at her watch] an age—I am such an impatient creature, I can't endure to wait a minute for any thing, and therefore never go to any public entertainment till after it begins. Is not that the right way, Sir Anthony? But I should not ask you, who are so phlegmatic, you could wait till dooms-day for any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Come, ma'am, you are too severe on my friend Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, this is but an inconsiderable speci∣men, a trifle, to what I could produce, of the severity I have received from this ungrateful fair-one.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: There is a gentleman below desires to speak with your Lordship on business.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I'll come to him—For Heaven's sake, ma'am, don't keep this poor lover any longer in expectation, but dismiss him fairly at once, for your own honour, as well as in pity to him. [Aside to Mrs. Knightly]. Sir Anthony, you'll excuse me for a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, I shall beg leave to wish your Lordship a good evening—I was just going away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Why sure you would not be such a clown as to leave me by myself, Sir Anthony! I can't go; for thinking that Lady Flutter was at home, I sent my chair to pay two or three visits—Now prithee sit down, and say some sprightly thing to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Ah Madam, my sprightly sallies were for happier days—
SP.L: When Flavia listened to my sighs,
That love which revell'd in my eyes

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I protest I did not know you were so good a poet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: The muses, Madam, are not such niggards of their favours. I have been indulged with some rapturous in∣tercourses with those ladies, I can assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh fy, Sir Anthony. What—tell tales?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: No aspersions, Madam—'tis very well known they are all virgins.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Well, but now let's hear what you can say to me in prose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Truly, Madam, this unexpected (I may say un∣hoped for) encounter, has so disconcerted me, that though I have much to say, I am utterly at a loss where to begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Why then don't begin at all, Sir Anthony; for I think you are generally more at a loss how to make an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, I must beg the favour of being allowed a hearing; a patient one, Madam; for such the nature of my case requires.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Is it a physical one, or a case of conscience, Sir Anthony?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Neither, Madam. I did propose to unfold my mind to you in a letter—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: But then if I should not unfold your letter, Sir Anthony, which is a thing might happen, in that case I should never know your mind, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: If you won't hear me, Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Well, well, I will hear you; but squeeze what you have to say into as small a compass as you can, my dear Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: The occasion, Madam, of my giving you this trouble (if as such you are pleased to consider it) is as follows. I have courted you, Madam, that is, made honourable addres∣ses to you, for the space of six months, during which time you gave me all the encouragement—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Encouragement! [screams] Oh, all you powers of chastity defend me!—Encouragement, Sir An∣thony! Of what nature, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Your pardon, Madam—Consistently with mode∣sty I mean; or such as became a virtuous Lady to bestow on a passionate admirer; for such I pronounce myself to have been.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh I understand you now—Well, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: For a time I was favoured with your smiles, and had reason to believe that my faithful passion would have been crowned with success; when all of a sudden, to my unuttera∣ble astonishment, the sun-shine of my hopes vanished.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I only stepp'd behind a cloud, Sir Anthony, to play at bo-peep with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Oh, Madam, a total eclipse, I do assure you.—My visits were repulsed, my letters unanswered, and fi∣nally your doors shut against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Did I do all this to poor Sir Anthony?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P:
You did, Madam—Tyrant, you know you did.
And now, Madam, I would fain learn your reasons for such usage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Reasons—I never gave a reason for any thing I did since I was born.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: That is rather extraordinary, Madam; but if you will not condescend to give me any reasons for your cru∣elty, all I have left to desire, or rather to demand, (pardon me the expression, Madam) is now, from your own lips, to receive my final doom.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Why, I shan't marry these ten years, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: That, Madam, is an indeterminate answer. I humbly request the favour of a final one

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Why what are you in such a hurry for? I protest, Sir Anthony, I begin to grow jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: A final answer, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I'll be hanged if I have not got a rival! Oh faithless man! that have sworn I don't know how many times over, to be true to me till death—and I, like the rest of my easy sex, to believe you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, let me most humbly beseech you—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Begone, dissembler—but what could I ex∣pect from such levity as yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Levity, madam! levity! I absolutely disavow the charge—pray, madam—let me implore you, for the last time (pray observe that, madam, for the last time) to grant me the favour—[He advances, bowing low, she flirts from him, and he catches hold of her sleeve.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Bless me! Why sure, Sir Anthony, you would not offer to kiss me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Oh heavens, madam, kiss you! Madam, let me take the liberty to inform you, that since I could distinguish between virtue and vice, I never took so unwarrantable a free∣dom with any lady upon the face of the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: My goodness! what's all this about? Mrs. Knightly, my dear, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I protest, my dear, your uncle is so very a∣morous, that it is not safe to stay alone with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, madam, I blush for you; humbly ask∣ing your pardon for being so free as to say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Blush for yourself, Sir Anthony, you have most cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What, in the name of wonder, is all this a∣bout?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh, Lady Flutter, I am ashamed to tell you his behaviour!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: My uncle's behaviour, madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, I hope my niece Flutter has too good an opinion of the propriety of my conduct upon all occasions, to be prejudiced by your uncharitable insinuations. And now, madam, I demand, in presence of my niece aforesaid, that you will give me a full and formal acquital of all my vows and pro∣mises to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I must take time to consider on that, Sir Anthony; vows are serious things; I suppose all yours are registered in Cupid's books.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I insist on my release, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I don't know whether it be safe to give you one, Sir Anthony; I must consult a lawyer first.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, I am sorry to say, that you depart ex∣tremely from that punctilious honour, as well as generosity of sentiment, which is such an ornament to the fair part of the creation—only ask for the favour of being discharged—a fa∣vour I was never refused by any lady before, I assure you, niece.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: That I dare say. [Aside.] Well, I can't for my life understand all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh he's a rebel in his heart, that's plain, and only wants a pretence to forfeit his allegiance; but I won't give him that satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Then, madam, since you urge me to it, in one word, I here cancel all my vows—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: It is not in your power.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Anth.
SP.P: Renounce your empire, madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I defy you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: And utterly disclaim your favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Stubborn traitor!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: And now, madam, I will withdraw my person and my heart—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Not your heart, Sir Anthony!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Both, both, madam, I do aver it to you; and will make an offering of them where they will be more honourably, and more gratefully entertained. And so, madam, I am, with proper respect, your most obedient (tho' rejected) humble servant. Niece Flutter, I have the pleasure of wishing you a very good evening.
SP.STAGE: [Exit Sir Anthony, bowing, both ladies burst out a-laughing.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.STAGE: [imitating his manner, looking after him, and curtsying very low.]
SP.P: And I return you my very unfeign∣ed acknowledgments for ridding me of your most insipid solem∣nity, my dear Sir Anthony. Ha, ha, ha, poor soul! to whom is he going to offer his Platonic adorations, do you know, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Why, by what I gather'd just now from the conversation between my Lord and him (for it was a secret to me before) I find Miss Medway is likely to supplant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Supplant me, my dear creature! why, sure you can't suppose I had ever any serious thoughts of the poor man; humbly begging your pardon, as he says, for taking such a liberty with your uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I should wonder if you had, I own; I am sure nothing but his fortune could have made my Lord think of him for a son-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Does Miss Medway approve of the thing? she is a sober sort of a girl, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh intolerably so; I hardly ever converse with her, tho' under the same roof. She is for ever poring o∣ver a book or a needle—Yet I don't suppose she likes him either; I have heard it whispered that she loves my cousin Branville, who, I hear, is expected home every hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P:
If I thought so, I would keep Sir
Anthony dangling this twelvemonth, out of mere compassion to the poor girl. For, notwithstanding his threats, I know he is still devoted to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: But how would that square with your views in regard to Colonel Medway?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh my sweet friend, that question has made me serious all at once. I can laugh at Sir Anthony no more; I have not lately had spirits enough to be diverted with him, and for that reason, tried to shake him off. I don't know what to think of the Colonel. I came here this evening on purpose to consult you. My Lord, who, I perceive, is a man of the world, and full of design, dropped some hints to me about his son, by which I find the thing would at least be very agreeable to him; yet the Colonel has not been near me since. I wish I knew his sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I am sure I can't inform you. There is none of the family very communicative, but my Lord; he is the best of them, that is certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Ha, Mrs. Knightly! my adorable! I kiss your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh, Sir Harry, you have missed such an entertainment! Here has been Sir Anthony—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Well, and what did uncle Parenthesis say to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh he has abandoned me—I am doomed to wear the willow garland.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Uh, you cruel devil you, 'tis you who have a∣bandoned him, I dare say—What, Lady Flutter! I am amaz∣ed to find you here; I thought you had abandoned me, as Mrs. Knightly says, and that by this time you had taken post for Oxfordshire, in order to tell papa, that Sir Harry was such a naughty boy, he would not give it its way in every thing. Mrs. Knightly, when I went out this evening, she was going to e∣lope, absolutely bent upon running away from her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P:
And you see, ma'am, the return he makes
me for my good nature in not doing so. I think, Sir Harry, after the provocation I received from you, if I changed my mind, you ought to be very much obliged to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: My dear, if the changing your mind be an obligation, I own my obligations to you on that score are in∣numerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I suppose you think that witty, now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Pray, pray, good people, am I to be left out of the conversation?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh, ma'am, my Lady Flutter is so extremely quick in her repartees, that you will find it very hard to put in a word, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: And Sir Harry is so immoderately fond of hearing himself talk, that he does not desire either of us to give him any interuption, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Not your Ladyship, I acknowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Well, I vow, Sir Harry, if you were my my husband, I should hate you, for all you are such a hand∣some toad.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Indeed you would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Indeed I should.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Go, you little hypocrite—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Get you gone, you rattlepate, I don't mind what you say—Come, Lady Flutter, will you go with me to the opera, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: With all my heart. Any-where rather than stay at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: You see, ma'am, what a happy man I am in do∣mestic felicity! But here, Lady Flutter, you must give me leave to interpose a little of my lawful authority; and there∣fore I desire, if it be not too great an honour, that you will oblige me with your company at home this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Indeed I shan't, Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Then, ma'am, I say, indeed you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P:
Bless me, Sir Harry, you an't serious, sure! I am vastly sorry I proposed the thing at all. I won't go to the opera for my part—I'll stay and chat with you, if you
will give me leave—or suppose we had a pool at piquett.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: By no means, ma'am. Why should you de∣prive yourself of your entertainment for her childishness? I'll attend you to the opera myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Indeed you shan't, for I won't go.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Indeed you shall, and I'll go with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I vow you shall neither of you go, and so good by to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: So, Sir Harry, you have exposed yourself prettily!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Not in the least, my dear; I have only shewn you to advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: It is well one of us has a little discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Meaning your wise self, I presume; but, to shew you that I have a small share too, I will enter into no farther disputes with you; but leaving you to your agreeable contemplations, follow my charming Mrs. Knightly to the opera, who, I fancy, will prefer my company to your Lady∣ship's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Very well, Sir!—if I am not even with you for this!—
SP.STAGE: Enter Lord Medway, at another door.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Alone ma'am! (I have been detained longer than I expected.) What is become of Mrs. Knightly and Sir An∣thony?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Both gone, my Lord—My uncle broke away in resentment, never, I think, to see her more.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: So, so—What have you done with Lady Med∣way and my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: They are at their evening meditations, I suppose, my Lord. They both came in with me, after we had made a short visit, but, according to custom, retired to my Lady's dressing-room.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, they read together every evening!—But you seem russled, my dear Lady Flutter; what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Sir Harry—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: He has been here since; but so intolerably rude and provoking, positively there is no enduring him any longer. I should be sorry to leave your Lordship's house so soon, where I have been so kindly received; but I am deter∣mined not to continue under the same roof with Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: If your departure were to be a punishment only to

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry,
SP.P: I should not oppose it; for I must allow, that he deserves all your resentment. But, my dear Lady Flutter, I could name another, whom you would make infinitely more unhappy by your absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Who can that be, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Suppose I were to name myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: You are very obliging, my Lord, I have not the least doubt of your friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Friendship, my dear ma'am, sometimes assumes a tenderer name—When a man entertains it for a woman, young and charming as you are, what ought it then to be called?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Why friendship, to be sure—what should it be else?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Shall I tell you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: No, I won't be told.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then you guess—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Not I, indeed, my Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: 'Tis love! love! is not that a sweeter sound?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: 'Tis a sound with which I am very little ac∣quainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then let me be your tutor, to teach you a science, in which Sir Harry is not worthy to instruct you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord, if I had met with you before I was married, and before you were married—But it is too late now—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You must not say so. What are marriage ties, if the hearts are not joined? 'Tis that alone which makes the union sacred.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: That is the chief thing, I grant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
Oh it is all in all!—With regard to Lady Med∣way
now; she is a good woman, it is true, and I esteem her as such; but there is no love in the case, so that I consider myself absolutely as a single man. 'Tis just the same with you; there has a ceremony indeed passed between you and Sir Harry; but he slights you, and you very justly despise him: so that, to all intents and purposes, you are a single woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I wish I were, I'm sure, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why so you are, my dear ma'am, if you would con∣sider the thing rightly—If I thought otherwise, tho' I con∣fess I love you to adoration, I would sooner stab myself to the heart, than endeavour to win your affections.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, I believe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
