SP.P: Then, since we are equally unhappy in wedlock, what crime can there be in our mutual endeavours to console each other?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I am sure I don't intend any harm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then why will you talk of leaving me? You know Sir Harry is too indifferent to be concerned at a separation; the grief, the disappointment, will all be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, I should be very unwilling to make you uneasy, to whom I owe so many obligations.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then speak no more of parting. [He takes her hand.] I have a thousand things to tell you. The delightful subject we are upon is inexhaustible, but I can never get you for half an hour to myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Why no, Sir Harry is so perpetually whif∣fling backwards and forwards, one can't be alone a minute for him.
SP.STAGE: [Lady Medway comes to the door, and steps back on seeing Lord Medway and Lady Flutter in such familiar confer∣ence.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I have thought of an expedient, which, if you will agree to, will secure us against all interruptions for the fu∣ture.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
You know Lady Lovegrove, who sat in the box
with us at the play the other night (a very worthy woman.) I am sure she would be glad of your acquaintance. I'll intro∣duce you to her, and there, you know, when you go of an e∣vening to drink tea, I can meet you, and we can enjoy an hour's conversation without being interrupted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I protest that will do very well. But we must not let Sir Harry know a word of my acquaintance with her, or may be, some evening, he'll be for thrusting himself in.

SP.SPEAKER: LOrd.
SP.P: By no means, he shall never be of our party. Come, ma'am, I fancy, by this time, the ladies have done with their sober studies—Suppose we were to join them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: As you will, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Not a word more of parting, remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I'll try what I can do to oblige your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh, Lord Medway! this is beyond what I thought you capable of; but I will, if possible, prevent the destruction that you have plann'd.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, changes to Widow Knightly's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Colonel Medway and Miss Richly.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I Would not have mentioned it at all, if I thought you could have suffered it to make so serious an im∣pression on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P:
It ought not, I confess, knowing as I do the truth and generosity of your heart—and yet I cannot help
being alarmed—an immense fortune, and a fine woman, as my sister really is—the temptation is so great! that were it any one but you—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear Clara, these fears of yours reproach, at the same time that they flatter me. Is it necessary that I should tell you, over and over again, for the thousandth time, that I never can love any woman but yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I do not want to be convinced—and yet I own I am pleased to hear you repeat even what you have said a thousand times; but your father's authority—I dread that.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Believe me, you have no reason; for, though no son was ever more observant of a father's will than I have always been of his; yet, in the particular concerns of my heart, I must be my own director. This my father knows, and I hope he will never urge me more upon the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: But if he should?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Would you have me swear to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Oh, not for the world!—I am ashamed of doubting, and yet I don't know how it is, I am full of appre∣hensions: the truth is, I am not very happy at home; my sis∣ter is, of late, grown cold and peevish to me—I never sus∣pected the cause before, but 'tis now too plain.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Did she ever mention me to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Never but in a careless way—and yet I think since your father's last visit to her, she has been in better spirits than before, though I am not used one bit the kinder.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You shall not long be subject to her tyranny. My fa∣ther already knows the secret of my love; and I think that, notwithstanding the article of fortune weighs much with him, his regard to my happiness will even out balance that.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I wish it may—Bless me! here's my sister.
SP.STAGE: She curtsies gravely to the Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I thought you had been alone, Miss Richly, and came to chat with you; but I see you are engaged.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I hope my being here, ma'am, will not deprive Miss Richly of the pleasure of your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I believe, sister, we shall both think our con∣versation very much improved by your making a third in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I don't know that—A tete a tete is to the full as often disagreeably inter rupted, as improved by another person.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: That, madam, I am sure, can never happen, where you make the addition

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I should be sorry it were the case now, I own, Colonel; for, to tell you the truth, I have vanity enough to be mortified at the thoughts of being considered as an in∣truder.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Bless me, madam! I know of but one circumstance in the world, which could possibly place you in such a light.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: What is that, pray sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Where an inferior beauty was meditating a conquest, and you stept in to snatch it from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: An inferior beauty—I protest, Colonel, I don't well understand that—There is an appearance of gal∣lantry in the compliment, and yet there is something a little mystical in it too. Clara, are you good at solving riddles?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: No, indeed, sister; you know I have a very lite∣ral understanding; besides, I think what the Colonel says re∣quires no explanation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Then, my dear, I won't affront you by making any application.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: If you should, sister, I am very ready to ac∣knowledge my part in it; but you should consider, that by the remainder, you would draw on yourself that imputation, which but now you wished to avoid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: You see, Colonel, the mysterious speech you have made has the fate of all oracles, to be interpreted diffe∣rent ways, and perhaps none of them right—Nay, I am in∣clined to think it bears a still nearer resemblance to them, and that you, like the priests of old, delivered what you said with∣out any inspiration of a god.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: There, madam, your comparison fails, for I assure you I am at this instant under the influence of a very powerful one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I vow I don't believe you; do you, Clara?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I never had any reason to doubt the Colonel's veracity, sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: What, then, you think he is really in love?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Don't you hear him acknowledge it?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Nay, madam, if you wo'nt take my word for it, I can't see what reason you have to believe any one's else.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Why no, that's true—But where a matter of faith does'nt concern one's self, infidelity, you know, can be of no great consequence one way or another.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: That's pretty home.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Very true, sister; but scepticism is a danger∣ous, as well as an uneasy state, in some cases.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: And a state of security, Miss Clara, the casuists in love, as well as religion, are agreed, is not always the safest. But I don't know how we fell upon this odd topic.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Nor I, I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I don't know how we came to talk of it; but I am convinced the man must be very insensible who could avoid thinking of it in this company.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Knightly.
SP.P: Clara, you are a monopolist; but I will have my share in that compliment—I don't know, Colo∣nel tho', what your mistress would say if she were to hear you say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: She'd forgive him, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Come, come, ladies, I see by your pursuing this sub∣ject, that you have a design of getting my secret out of me; and, as I am sure I could not withstand your united force, I think my safest way is to make my retreat before I betray my∣self—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: How long was the Colonel here before I came in, Clara?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Not above a quarter of an hour—Pray, sister, why do you ask?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Knightly.
SP.P:
Because it is quite astonishing to me, how
a man of his vivacity can be entertained by such a piece of still-life as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Why, sister, it is not an in-falli-ble maxim, that we most admire those who are exactly of our own dispo∣sition. I, now, for example, who am naturally grave, do, notwithstanding, admire sprightliness in other people.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Umph, so it seems—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: And the Colonel, tho' extremely lively him∣self, may, however, not disrelish the conversation of a serious woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Indeed, Clara, you are a very conceited girl. I dare swear, if the Colonel says fine things to you, you believe every word of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Indeed, sister, I have as humble an opinion of myself, as you, or any one else can possibly have of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I am very glad to hear it, child; for I own I think vanity would not be a very desirable companion in your situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: What have I done, sister, to deserve these severe taunts from you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh, Clara, if you accuse me of severity, I must tell you that you are an ungrateful girl, and I fancy we shall not continue much longer together.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I am not quite so destitute, madam, but that I can still be received by that friend who had the care of me from my childhood.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Very well, madam, I shall consider of it; but perhaps I may find out some more eligible place for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I see, sister, you are resolved to disapprove of every thing I say or do; my company is become irksome to you, and, for the present at least, I'll rid you of it—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P:
I was very unlucky in ever taking her into my house; had it not been for that, I should never, perhaps, have seen the only man who probably could have given me a minute's uneasiness.—I am puzzled at his conduct—and yet I suspect now more than ever that they love each other—If it be so, I shall know it too soon, for I am sure Lord Med∣way
is thoroughly in my interests;—yet my suspense is in∣supportable.—Who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Madam, your chair is ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Come hither—I desire you will give or∣ders to the servants, that any letters directed to my sister should be brought to me—I suspect that girl has got into a silly intrigue.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: I believe, madam, Miss receives letters very often; but I shall take care, for the future, that you shall have them first.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Be sure you do—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Good morning to your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I was afraid you were not well, Lady Flutter, as you lay abed so long this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I rested ill last night, nothing more.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I hope I don't interrupt you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Not in the least; but I vow you are so ce∣remonious, Lady Medway, that you will not allow me to think myself at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I should be sorry for that, madam; but you know there are times when one would not chuse to be broke in upon by any one; yet, to shew you how free I make with you, I have brought my work with me, if you will let me pore a lit∣tle at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I wish she and her work were far enough. (A∣side.) Your Ladyship is excessively obliging. You and Miss Medway are such housewives, you quite shame me—This is prodigiously pretty; who are these ruffles for?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Lord, to be sure—Where is Sir Harry this morning? I have not seen him yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Dear Lady Medway, don't ask me about him, for I know nothing of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: What, not of your husband, my dear! Well, well, Lady Flutter, when your young necks are a little more inured to the marriage yoke, I hope it will sit easier on you both—This work blinds me, I'll lay it by—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh impossible! he grows worse and worse every day. There never was such an incorrigible ill-natured thing in the universe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Now, really, there I must differ from you; I never took Sir Harry to be ill-natured; hasty and petulant, I grant you, he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Madam, I hope you will allow me to be the best judge.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: You have reason to be so, I own; but a stander-by may form an opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I don't know what your Lady-ship's opinion may be; but I am sure it is the opinion of others, and some that I could name of undoubted good judgment, that there never was, since the creation, a woman so unfortunate in a husband as I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh, Lord Medway, what have you to answer for! (Aside.) I must say, Lady Flutter, that if it even were so (which, heaven knows, is far from being the case), they are not your friends, no more than Sir Harry's, who would en∣deavour to persuade you to such a belief.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Bless me, ma'am! Why, isn't it visible to all the world? Doesn't all the town ring of his ridiculous beha∣viour, and wonder at my patience in bearing it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Indeed, Lady Flutter, I believe you are mistaken. The town have something else to mind beside little domestic quarrels that no way concern them; and I dare say, no-body but your particular friends trouble their heads about it. Tho', I must observe, that had both you and Sir Harry been a little less communicative, even to some of your friends, on the sub∣ject of your disagreement, it might have been happier for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P:
Oh, dear ma'am! I know there are some tame wives in the world, who can submit in silence to any
usage; but I am not one of those, I assure you. I have not been used to controll, nor I won't be controll'd, that's more.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Softly, dear Lady Flutter, I don't mean to offend you; I would argue with you as a friend. Pray speak low∣er; I would not have any of our servants hear on what sub∣ject we are discoursing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Gracious! why, every servant in the house knows how we live.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But, madam, don't you think your unguarded complaints without doors, and perhaps your unadvised choice of confidants within, may lead you into some inconvenience?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I don't well understand your question, Lady Medway; my choice of confidants within—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Yes—male ones, I mean; for example now, if a young married lady should make choice of a gentleman to whom she should open her heart, and let him so far into her confidence as to tell him she despises her husband, what do you think must be the consequence?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What! why, I suppose he'd think—he'd imagine—I don't know what he'd think—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I'll tell you; he'd think, perhaps, that a liking to him had as great a share in the lady's contempt for her hus∣band, as any real fault of the husband's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: If he thought so, I could not help it; but I am sure there is no one to whom I complain will draw any such inference.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: There is nothing but what is very natural in all this, Lady Flutter; and the gentleman, on this supposition, will think himself bound to make an offer of his love to the lady; she, perhaps, receives it—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Lord, ma'am! these are strange conclu∣sions—What can she mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: If this should be the case, what must ensue! Oh, Lady Flutter, an innocent young creature like you, should start at the thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Upon my word, Lady Medway, I don't understand such insinuations. If Sir Harry insults me, I am not obliged to bear it from every one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I am sorry, madam, that you consture a friendly cau∣tion into an insult. I am your friend, perhaps the only one who has the power of saving you from destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Destruction! madam, I could not have expec∣ed this from you, in your own house. I believe my Lord would not thank you for treating me thus—but if you are tired of me, madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh, my dear madam! you are in a very great error, my Lord is the greatest enemy you have in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: You may happen to be mistaken in that, La∣dy Medway, as well as in other things.—Poor woman, she little knows—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Come, not to play at cross-purposes with you any longer, I must tell you that I am no stranger to my Lord's de∣signs on you—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: His designs on me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Yes, madam, his cruel, his (I grieve to say) infamous designs on you. Oh, Lady Flutter, you stand on a dreadful precipice! do not reject the kind hand that would snatch you from certain ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: This is such extraordinary language, Lady Medway, that really—I don't know what to say to it—I little imagined I should have created any jealousy when I came into your family.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear, you entirely mistake my motive. I own there was a time when I might have been influenced by jealousy, but I have out-lived it; and am not now actuated by so selfish a passion. Pity to your inexperienced youth, friend∣ship to your worthy parents, regard to the honour of your hus∣band, joined to the tenderness and duty I owe my Lord, are the sole motives which urge me to save you all, if possible, from ruin. I know my Lord makes love to you; and that you have, unwarily, been drawn in to make an assignation with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: If he has been so treacherous as to tell this!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
He has not, I assure you; yet I am certain of the fact; I know too well the nature of his connections with Lady Love∣grove—And now, my dear, if you would escape the snare
which is laid for your undoing, be advised by me, who am your true friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I don't think I have a friend in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: You are mistaken; I am sincerely so. My Lord is a man of pleasure, and is perhaps less scrupulous in affairs of gallantry, than in any other vice. Your youth and agreeable person were alone sufficient to attract him; but when superad∣ded to this, he found you despised your husband, and made no difficulty of owning it to him, it almost amounted to an in∣vitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: An invitation, Lady Medway! you use me very ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: To a man of his cast, madam, it certainly does. Your unacquaintedness with men of intrigue makes you blind to your own danger; but indeed, Lady Flutter, there is but one step between you and inevitable shame and misery. What do you think must be the consequence, if Sir Harry should dis∣cover that you have appointed a private place of meeting with my Lord? What must he think of the nature of a correspon∣dence thus meanly carried on by stealth? Ask your own heart if you can justify this to your husband and to your friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Lord bless me, Lady Medway!—you terri∣fy me—I am amazed how you came to the knowledge of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: 'Tis a happiness to you, madam, that I have, if by it I can be the means of saving you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I own I was a fool for consenting; but sure, madam, you won't be so barbarons as to tell Sir Harry; it would give him such an advantage over me, I can't bear the thoughts of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Why really, my dear, I should be sorry to be under the necessity of taking so disagreeable a step; and if I thought I could rely on your honour and discretion, in your future con∣duct, I certainly should keep your secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Madam, I'll quit your house directly, if that will satisfy you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
By no means, madam; how would you answer that to your friends, if they should enquire the reason? Here you
came to town to stay the winter with me, and before a month's elapsed you quit my house!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Why, I can tell them that Sir Harry is so in∣sufferable, I can't live with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: If you will be ruled by me, Lady Flutter, for one week, nay but for three days, I'll engage that Sir Harry and you shall be as happy a couple as any in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh gracious! you could as soon convert us into angels.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But will you promise to be guided by me, but for a little while?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: O dear Lady Medway, I know you would recommend patience and submission, and all that; but I ne∣ver can, nor ever will submit to his humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Why then, madam, I shall think it my duty to write to your father immediately, and let him know the danger of your situation; for though I am sure the parting you from your husband would afflict him, yet 'tis better he should receive you while you are innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What is it you would have me do, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Your task is not hard, if you are disposed to set a∣bout it. You are married to a very young man, Lady Flutter; who, though he is warm and volatile, does not want sense, and I am sure is good-natured in the main.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Dear Lady Medway—you are enough to turn one's brain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Hear me out, madam. You, on the other hand, who have as much sense, and as much good-nature as he, are at the same time a little too quick and impatient of contradiction. He I will allow is too ready to give offence; but you in your turn must grant, that you are as sudden in taking it. Now, my dear, 'tis in your power, and give me leave to tell you, 'tis your duty also, to correct yours. And I'll answer for it that Sir Harry will follow your lead; for I am sure that he loves you a great deal better than my Lord does, let him tell you what he pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I wish I could see any proofs of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Will you make the experiment?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: What and give up to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Only for once, just for a trial; if he does not re∣ceive it as he ought, I will never desire you to repeat it—I think I hear his rap at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Well, madam, to show you that it is not my fault that we live so uneasily, I will do as you would have me; you yourself shall be the judge; but then remember you are not to write to my papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I will not, and remember you are not to have any private conferences with my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: How does your Ladyship do this morning? [To lady Medway.] I am tired to death, I have been at my ban∣ker's, and jolting all over the detestable city.—Defend me! Why your head is dressed so barbarously, Lady Flutter, you look like ten furies; by my life, an absolute Medusa; prithee who gave thee that formidable appearance, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I am sorry you don't like it, Sir Harry; I'll not employ that Frenchman any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Then I am sure you don't like it yourself; for Sir Harry's judgment has not the happiness of having any great weight with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: No, I protest I think it quite becoming and genteel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Then it must be to oblige you, Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Undoubtedly, ma'am, that's her study.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir Harry, I would make it so, if you would let me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: My dear! say that over again pray; it sounds vastly pretty, if it were but true.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Why then seriously I would rather dress to please you than any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Hark'ee Lady Flutter, Irony is a mighty ticklish weapon, and you handle it very aukwardly, upon my soul; lay it by, or you'll cut your fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I declare and vow I am in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh dear ma'am, your most obedient—but you're a bungler, take my word for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But, Sir Harry, why should you doubt that Lady Flutter is serious?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Why really, ma'am, because I never knew Lady Flutter serious in any thing, but her endeavours to make herself disagreeable to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: In which I sancy however she has not succeeded, Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: If that be the case, then I am resolved to take another course, and to try what my endeavours to please him will do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: What do you say to that, Sir Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Say! 'gad, I don't well know what to say to it. There is something devilish pleasant in hearing her talk so, if the humour would but last.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Take my word for it, Sir Harry, it will be your own fault if it does not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Faith, ma'am, I should be glad to keep up the ball as long as I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Indeed, indeed, Sir Harry, I will never quar∣rel with you again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Upon your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Nor I with you, upon my soul—And shall we grow fond of one another?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Immensely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Agreed—I'll never find fault with any thing you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Nor I with any thing you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: I'll never contradict you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Nor I you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Sweet rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: My dear Sir Harry!
SP.STAGE: [He takes her hand and kisses it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Well now is not this charming?—I congratulate
you both on your happiness, and leave you to the enjoyment of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Duce take me but I should think you prodigi∣ous agreeable, if you were always in good humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: And, upon my life, I should think the same of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: How came we not to discover this sooner?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Because we never tried to find it out. Lady Medway was the first that told me we might be happy if we pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Faith then she has more sagacity than my Lord; for he was of a contrary opinion, and used to pity me of all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: For being married to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Really!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Truth, upon my word.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I see his treachery. [Aside.] Then, Sir Har∣ry, I will convince him of his error, by making the best wife in the world, in spite of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Charming creature! I shall grow too fond of you—I won't let you be so engaging, hussy—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: You shall tho'—
SP.STAGE: Enter Lord Medway, who stops on seeing Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Pray, my Lord, come in—I have a sad com∣plaint to make to you. This is certainly the most perverse girl!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh Sir Harry, that is the old story—I won't hear what you have to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: But, my Lord, this is new, a quite spick and span new affair. She has taken such a resolution!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Not to part I hope!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: No, no, my Lord, a much stranger thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Ay! what can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: You will be amazed when I tell you—We were disputing about it when you came in—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am sorry, Sir Harry, to find you always in disputes with your Lady. I wish from my heart I could compose your differences—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh she is the very spirit of contradiction, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Depend upon it, Sir Harry, I will have my own way in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And in every thing else, I'll be sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: You must not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That's right. [Aside to Lady Flutter.] What is the matter in debate?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Why, my Lord, 'tis the oddest thing in the world; she is resolved right or wrong, in spite of all I can say—to be very good—and make me love her whether I will or not—Don't you think that is monstrously provoking?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: And he, my Lord, has taken up as unac∣countable a design—of never contradicting me in any thing—Is not that as provoking?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: A'n't we a couple of fools, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why, really, Sir Harry,—if this could be—I can't say—I am sure I sincerely wish to see you both in good terms—and if you have found out a way—with all my heart.
SP.STAGE: [Sir Harry and Lady Flutter both burst out a laughing.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am glad to see you so merry, my young gentry—I wish it may last, that's all. Sir Harry, I have a word to say to you. Why you are undone, man, if once you let her turn matters to ridicule.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh my Lord, you are quite mistaken, all this is serious.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Come, I'll have no plotting.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Poh, poh, she will get the better of you I see—[Aside to Sir Harry.] Let me speak to her—Lady Flutter!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: The tables are turned, my Lord; I'll whis∣per with no body but Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But two words—When shall we meet?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Never [Aside to Lord Medway.]—Sir Harry, now that you intend to be very fond of me, I desire that you will grow a little jealous, and tell my Lord that he must not come into my dressing-room in a morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Faith, my Lord, that's true, I begin not to re∣lish the Spartan scheme as well as I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Mighty fine! this is an extraordinary metamorpho∣sis, if it holds—but of that I own I have some doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: You need not fear, my Lord—We have your good wishes that it should, I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That's home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Come, Sir Harry, I want to go to an auction this morning; will you be so good as to give me your com∣pany?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: With all my heart, my dear, I'll attend you; and see here I received all this to day! [Takes out a purse, which she snatches from him.] Oh you little plunderer! give me a kiss for it—I'll have another—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Go, you extortioner—day, day, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What can be the meaning of all this? damned little cocquet—So much art at her years!—or is it owing to my wife's interposition? Yet she knew not of my design—Any way I am ashamed to be bassled so ridiculously—And that puppy Sir Harry too—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir Anthony Branville's come to wait on your Lord∣ship—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Shew him into my study—Here's another fool that don't know his own mind; but I'll fix him one way on other, if I can.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE changes to Lord Medway's study.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Anthony and Lord Medway, meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
Sir Anthony, I am glad to see you; I was really in great pain for you yesterday, when I was obliged to leave you
in the magic circle of Mrs. Knightly's charms; I wish you joy of your escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, I humbly thank you; 'tis a felicity to me I acknowledge; for, my Lord, there never was such a Syren, such a Circe! Scylla and Charybdis (of whom we read in sable) were harmless innocents to her; but, Heaven be prais∣ed, I am my own man again; and now, my Lord, I am come, agreeably to the intimation I gave you before, to make a most respectful offering of my heart, to the truly deserving and fair Lady, Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, I have already told you I shall be proud of your alliance, and my daughter I make no doubt is sensible of your worth!—Therefore, Sir Anthony, the shorter we make the wooing—women are slippery things—you un∣derstand me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Your Lordship's insinuation, though derogatory to the honour of the fair-sex, (which I very greatly reverence) has, I am apprehensive a little too much veracity in it. I have found it so to my cost; for would you believe it, my Lord, this cruel woman, (Mrs. Knightly, I mean, begging her pardon for the epithet) is the eighth lady to whom I have made sincere, humble, and passionate love, within the space of these last thirteen years.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You surprize me, Sir Anthony; is it possible that a gentleman of your figure and accomplishments could be re∣jected by so many?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I do not positively affirm, my Lord, that I was re∣jected by them all; no, my Lord, that would have been a se∣verity not to be survived—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: How was it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Blemishes, my Lord, foibles, imperfections in the fair ones, which obliged me (though reluctantly) to withdraw my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Ho ho, why then the fault was your's, Sir Anthony, not theirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P:
I deny that, my Lord; with due submission to your better judgment, it was their fault, for the truth is, I
never could get any of them to be serious. There is a levity, my Lord, a kind of (if I may so call it) instability, which runs through the gentler sex (whom nevertheless I admire) which I assure you has thus long deterred me from wedlock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then, Sir Anthony, I find you have been peculiarly unfortunate in the ladies whom you have addressed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Supremely so, my Lord; for notwithstanding that they all received my devoirs most indulgently, yet I do not know how it was, in the long run they either absolutely refus∣ed making me happy, or else were so extremely unguarded in their conduct, even before my face, that I thought I could not, consistency with honour, confer the title of Lady Branville on any one of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Your lot has been a little hard I must confess. I hope however that honour has been reserved by fate for my daugh∣ter. She is your ninth mistress, Sir Anthony, and that you know is a propitious number.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, I take the liberty of hoping so too; and that she is destined to recompence me, for the disappointments and indignities I have received, from the rest of woman-kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why then, Sir Anthony, I suppose I may now pre∣sent you to her in the character of a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, I pant for that happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I'll call her, Sir Anthony—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: As your Lordship pleases—but, my Lord, this widow Knightly—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Was there ever such a phlegmatic blockhead! [A∣side.] What of her, Sir Anthony?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I own I loved her better than any of her prede∣cessors in my heart—Matters indeed had gone farther between us, for, my Lord, (not to injure a lady's reputation) I must tell you a secret—I have more than once pressed her hand with these lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Really!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P:
Fact upon my veracity; I hope your Lordship don't think me vain: and as she had indulged me such lengths,
could I be censured for raising my wishes to the possession of this beauty?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: By no means, Sir Anthony; but then her ill behavi∣our to you—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord, it has blotted, and as I may say totally erased her image from my breast—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I'll bring my daughter to you, whose i∣mage I hope will supply her's in your breast.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I hope this tender fair one will not be too easily won—that would debase the dignity of the passion, and deprive me of many delightful hours of languishment—There was a time when a lover was allowed the pleasure of importuning his mistress, but our modern beauties will scarce permit a man that satisfaction. Pray heaven my intended bride may not be one of those—If it should prove so—I tremble for the consequences;—but she comes, the con∣descending nymph approaches.
SP.STAGE: Enter Louisa, led in by Lord Medway.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Louisa, you are no stranger to Sir Anthony Branville's merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Oh my Lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That he is a gentleman of family and fortune, of most unblemished honour, and very uncommon endowments.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Oh, my good Lord, ordinary, slight accomplish∣ments.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You are therefore to think yourself happy in being his choice, preferably to any other lady. And now, Sir Anthony, I'll leave you to pursue your good fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa
SP.P: Sir, won't you please to fit?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Miss Medway, madam—having obtained my Lord your father's permission, I humbly presume to approach you in the delightful hope, that after having convinced you of the excess of my love—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I hope, Sir Anthony, you will allow me a reasonable time for this conviction!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P:
Madam, I should hold myself utterly abandon∣ed
if I were capable at the first onset (notwithstanding what passes here) of urging a lady on so nice a point.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I thank you, Sir; but I could expect no less from a gentleman whom all the world allows to be the very pat∣tern of decorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: 'Tis a character, madam, that I have always been ambitious of supporting, whatever struggles it may cost me from my natural fervor; for let me tell you, madam, a beau∣tiful object is a dangerous enemy to decorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: But your great prudence, Sir Anthony, leaves me no room to suspect—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I am obliged to call it to my aid I do assure you, madam; for spite of the suggestions of passion, I by no means approve of those rash and impetuous lovers, who, without regard to the delicacy of the lady, would, (having obtained consent) as it were rush at once into her arms, you'll pardon me, madam, for so grossly expressing my idea.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Oh, Sir Anthony, I am charmed with your notions, so refined! so generous! and I must add (though it may ap∣pear vain) so correspondent with my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, I am transported to hear you say so! I am at this minute in an absolute extacy! Will you permit me, dear madam, the ravishing satisfaction of throwing my∣self at your feet?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: By no means, Sir Anthony; I could not bear to see a gentleman of your dignity in so humble a posture; I will suppose it done if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I prostrate myself in imagination, I assure you madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Now, Sir Anthony, as you see my papa is impati∣ent for the honour of being related to you, and that I am bound to an implicit obedience, I am afraid, unless your pru∣dence interposes, that we shall both be hurried into wedlock, with a precipitancy very inconsistent with pro priety.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I declare, madam, I am of your ladyship's opinion, and am almost apprehensive of the same thing—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: How is this to be avoided, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Be assured, madam, I too well know what is due to virgin modesty, to proceed with that rapidity, which my Lord (with whom I have not the honour of agreeing in this particular) seemeth to recommend.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You are very kind, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Oh, madam, I should pay but an ill compliment to your transcending merit, if I did not think it worth sighing for a considerable time longer, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: That's very noble in you, Sir Anthony—So passionate! and yet so nice—if all lovers were but like you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: The world I will presume to say would be the better, madam—but then I hope your rigours will not extend too far, my dear lady—a few months or so—longer than that I should be very near tempted to call cruel, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: As my passionate lover seems so well disposed to wait, I may chance to escape him. [Aside.] Your extraor∣dinary merit, Sir Anthony, will undoubtedly shorten your time of probation—Mean while as I hinted to you before, that my papa is rather in haste to call you son, I would not have him imagine that I give any delay to this union. He may call my duty in question, which he expects should keep pace with his own wishes—you apprehend me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Perfectly, my dear madam, and if I presume to interpret what you have so charmingly insinuated to my apprehension, you would have me just hint to my Lord, that you are not quite averse to honouring me with your fair hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: That I am ready to do so, if you please, Sir An∣thony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Very good, but at the same time I shall give him to understand that I am not as yet intitled to receive that very great happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: To that purpose, Sir, for I would not have this necessary delay appear to be of my chusing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: You little know, madam, the violence I do my∣self to repress the ardor of my flames; but patience is a prime virtue in a lover, and Scipio himself never practised self-de∣denial with more success than I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I rely entirely on your discretion, Sir Anthony, to manage this affair with my papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Oh, madam, I shall convince my Lord, that it is from very sublime motives I submit to postpone my felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I am much obliged to you, Sir Anthony, for this generous proof of your passionate regard to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: You'll find, madam, I do not love at the ordi∣nary rate—but I must not indulge myself too long on the tender subject. I doubt it is not safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sir, I won't detain you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I must absolutely tear myself from you, madam, for gazing on so many charms I may grow unmindful of the danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sir, I will no longer trespass on your time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I must fly, madam, lest I should be tempted to transgress those rigid bounds I have prescribed to myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sir—you have my consent to retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I am so overpowered with transport, madam, that I hold it necessary to withdraw.—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: 'Tis the best way, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Dear madam, vouchsafe one gracious smile to your adorer.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, you humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, your most devoted—oh dawning of ecstatic bliss!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, I think I may now go, and very safe∣ly assure my papa, that I am ready to take my adorer when∣ever he pleases—this is fortunate beyond my hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: THERE's nothing good or ill but by comparison—Confound your dry maxims, what are they good for? (He throws away the book.) Yet there is some truth in that too.—Yesterday I thought myself an unhappy man—but what am I this morning? So much worse, that when I compare the two conditions, I now think I was happy yesterday.—My affairs are in a hopeful condition truly! Ruined in my fortune, jilted by my mistress, disobeyed by my son, in∣sulted by my wife's superior worth; and last night (thanks to my dear indulgent stars!) to sum up all, I was forced to pawn the only stake I had left, my honour; which when I shall re∣deem, heaven knows.—All is now lost; and if my son con∣tinues obstinately to refuse this match, I am irretrievably un∣done—What can these chits want?
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Harry and Lady Flutter, arm in arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: My Lord, I am in the greatest surprise in the world!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: At what, Sir Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: At something my wife here has told me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sure she has not blabbed! [Aside.] What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Something of your Lordship, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Of me, ma'am! I hope I have done nothing, ma'am, that—that deserves censure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Egad, my Lord, you have tho', and very severe censure too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir Harry, I am ready to answer any charge against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, neither Sir Harry nor I come to challenge you, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, faith my Lord looks as grave as if he were afraid of it tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Afraid of it, Sir Harry! pray change that word for a better.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: I vow, my Lord, you look as if you had a mind to beat us both—doesn't he, Sir Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir Harry, I have really some serious business on my hands, and should be glad if you would dispatch what you have to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: What I have to say, my Lord, why all the world have it to say, as well as I.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What is it, pry'thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Why, that you are going to force Miss Med∣way to marry an old hero in tapestry hanging.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Is that all!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: All! and enough too, in conscience, I think; why what the duce, my Lord, it is the jest of the town alrea∣dy, Lady Flutter and I have so laughed at the thoughts of it this morning We call him the Knight of the inflexible coun∣tenance.
SP.STAGE: [Here Sir Harry and Lady Flutter burst out a-laugh∣ing.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh! I am mighty glad to see you so much of one mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: My Lord, as we are entirely indebted to your good offices for that union, I am sure it must give you pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Sarcastical gipsey! but come, we won't ban∣ter his Lordship about it; he meant us well, I believe, though he was a little out in his politics—for faith, my Lord, I think she is much the better since I have given her her own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am glad of it, Sir.—Have you any thing father to offer?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Nothing, but our good advice, my Lord; as we have received so much from you, I think we owe you some in return; and, I am sure, if you would take mine, you would not think of my uncle for a son-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh fy, fy! ridiculous to the last degree.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Positively, my Lord, I won't give consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I suppose your uncle's at age, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Oh la! he has been that these hundred years.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why then—excuse me, I am not at present in a humour to trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: But we are, my Lord; an't we, Sir Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh eternally, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Be so good, then, as to enjoy it without my partici∣pation—I am really busy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Come, Sir Harry. He's so splenetic, there is no bearing him. Let's go and laugh by ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Oh there's no pleasure like it!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: My Lord could tell us of others, I warrant; well, don't look so cross; we'll dance at the wedding, if it must be a match.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: I dare say your uncle will have jousts and tour∣naments; I'll learn to handle a target, my Lord, against the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: My Lord don't think us worthy of an answer, so we will leave him to his wise reflections.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: A couple of impertinents.—He alarmed me at first, but I find she is too cunning to tell him all.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I met Sir Anthony just going to my sister, my Lord; I suppose matters are in a favourable train between them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: He is such an out of the way fellow, there is no knowing what to make of him; he has been with me and quite tired me with his romantic absurdity; but I think it will be a match. Your sister has at last condescended to ac∣cept of him for a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I am glad of it, my Lord, since it was a thing you wished.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I thank you, son.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Something has ruffled you, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I have an affair, George, that lies heavy on my spirits—'Tis in you power, and I think—I hope at least—in your inclination, to extricate me from the greatest difficulty in which I was ever yet involved

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P:
My Lord, you know you may command me; I am
ready to hazard my life for your service, if it be any thing of that nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: No, no, no; I am not so old, Medway, as to require the assistance of your sword.—You mistake my meaning quite.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You seem moved, my Lord,—[Lord Medway walks about]—pray explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Faith, son, I am almost ashamed to tell you the di∣stress I have brought both upon myself and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Dear, my Lord, don't think of me in the case.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Last night, George, I lost two thousand pounds, which I was obliged to pay this morning, and my honour is engaged for almost as much more.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I thought you had determined never to ven∣ture on such deep play again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I had so; but something happened yesterday that vexed and disconcerted me, and I went to the old set, just to amuse myself for an hour; but I don't know how it was—they drew me in for half the night.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I am exceedingly concerned; but what can I do now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why, there's the point—I am very loth to revive a subject, that I know is disagreeable to you; but you see to what distress I am driven—there is but one way left.—You remember what we talked of yesterday; if my curst ill fortune had not pursued me last night, I thought never to have mentioned it to you again.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I flattered myself you never would.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I thought I should not have occasion. I had another thing in view; but this last blow has crushed all my hopes at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Is it not practicable, my Lord, to devise some other way?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh impossible! I am overwhelmed with debts, and worried like a stag at bay; but with regard to this last, for which my honour's pawned, I must be speedy in the means of payment.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, I am exceedingly shock'd at what you tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And is that all I am to expect from you? Look ye, Medway, it does not become a father to entreat a son; neither is it suitable to your age, or the character you bear in life, to be threatened, like a sniv'ling girl, with parental authority; mine is impotent, for I have nothing left to bestow; but as you would wish to prosper hereafter, save your father from dis∣grace, your mother (a good one she has been to you) from pe∣nury.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I call Heaven to witness I would give up my life to preserve you both; but you require what is infinitely more precious!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh fy! fy upon it! how like a woman this is!—Your sister, a romantic girl, could do no more than sooth me with fine speeches; I expected a more substantial proof of filial love from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, you wound me deeply by such a cruel charge. What have I not already done to shew my duty, or, what with me was much stronger, my love for you, my Lord? Have I not given up my birth-right? put it wholly in your power to alienate for ever, if you please, my family inheri∣tance, and leave me a beggar? Is not this a substantial proof? My Lord, I beg your pardon; but you have wrung my very heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And you have wrung mine—for, Medway, with equal grief and shame I speak it, I have made you a beggar; I have mortgaged the last foot of land I was possessed of in the world, and the only prospect I had of redeeming it, was by this lady's fortune; that would have recovered all, and restored you to the estate of your ancestors. I thought a boyish passi∣on might have been overcome, when such important motives for it were united, as your own interest, and the honour of your family.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: As for my own interest, my Lord, it is but a feather in the scale; and for the rest, I think my own honour (which you yourself taught me to prize) is more concerned in this event, than that of my family can possibly be.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You told me you were not engaged by promise to the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I am not, my Lord; but are there no ties but what the law can vindicate? Oh my Lord, you forget the lessons you have given me on other occasions!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Well, well—I acknowledge the justness of your re∣proach; but it comes like a bearded arrow from a child's lips—But I have done—I give up the cause—Had this affair, on which I had set my heart, succeeded, I should per∣haps have been happier than I desire to be—I had this morn∣ing been laying down a plan—but no matter, it is all over—I am sorry your mother should be a suffer with me—I have not been the kindest husband—but I did intend, after I had seen you and my daughter settled, to have retired into the country on a moderate annuity; and there, Medway, I might perhaps have led a very different life from what you have been used to see; but I must struggle with ill fortune as well as I can—You have been a worthy son, I acknowledge it—You have done enough—You shall not charge me with making you miserable for life.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord, I wish you had kept up your resentment; I cannot bear to hear you talk in this strain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why not, man? 'tis nothing but the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I would do any thing to prevent—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What? Speak, George.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I can't, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: A father's ruin, you would say—I know the ten∣derness of your nature, Medway, and therefore I will not urge you; your father is not such a tyrant; I have always consider∣ed you as my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, to deserve that title still, I must not see you unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why evill-ingly, I think you would not—nor would I make you so for the world—I have already hurt you but too much. I will not wrong you every way. I deserve the ruin I have brought upon myself, and am content to sink un∣der it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, that must not be while I have power to help it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I cannot ask it, son.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I'll give up all—even my love, to save you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You cannot mean it sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I'll do as you would have me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What! marry Mrs. Knightly?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I will, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Give me your hand—Oh, George, what a triumph is yours!—You make me ashamed.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, since your affairs are urgent, I will not trust to the wavering of my own heart; I will visit her this morn∣ing; but it will be proper first to apprize poor Miss Richly of this sudden change.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: By all means; but take my advice, Medway, and do not trust yourself to see her. Write what you have to say, for sighgs and tears are infectious things. But all I hope will soon blow over; and when you are married, you may then have it in your power to make amends for the fortune she has lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I dare not permit myself to think upon the subject—I will take your advice, and write to her whilst my resolution's warm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Do so then; mean while I'll prepare Mrs. Knightly (as we know each other's mind on the occasion) to receive you in a character in which I am sure she longs to receive you; but, my dear Medway, assume a chearful air when you visit her; that look would throw a damp on all.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I'll do my best, my Lord, to disguise both my counte∣nance and my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Worthy creature! it almost goes against me to let him complete this match. Yet what other resource have I left? I hope this lady may make him happier than he expects—But I must haste and write to her directly, to request that as a favour, which I am sure she will think her greatest happi∣ness.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to Mrs. Knightly's house.
DIV3.STAGE: Mrs. Knightly, as just coming in, giving her capuchin, &c. to her Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Has any one been here since I went out?

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: No, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Nor any letter or message?

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Not that I know of, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Go and send Miss Richly to me. [Exit Maid.] What a mortifying situation am I in! to have made advances to a man, who, instead of stepping forward to receive them, shrinks back—My Lord Medway I know would gladly pro∣mote a union between his son and me. The backwardness on his side then, can proceed from no other cause, but a pre-en∣gagement of his heart. Yet that may be got over; but if (as I fear) my sister loves him, I must not come to any explanation with her; for whilst I seem ignorant of it, I am not obliged to compliment her at the expence of my own quiet—I begin to wish her out of my sight.
Have you done the work I left you, with Clara?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I did not imagine you had given it to me as a task, sister—I have done nothing to it yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I cannot conceive what you have got into that head of yours, child; for of late you never do any thing that I desire—I think I never saw so strange an alteration.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Excuse me, sister, the alteration is in you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh your servant, ma'am, you have learnt to contradict too—but it would become you, Clara, to re∣member I am your elder sister; and tho'there is no great diffe∣rence in our years, yet I think the state you are in should teach you a little more respect to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Indeed, sister, I do not want to be hourly re∣minded of that; I am sufficiently humbled already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P:
Upon my word, Clara, I believe you will
find humility the most useful virtue you can practise; and that you may have a better opportunity of doing so, I have thought of placing you in a sober retired family in the country; and who knows but you may captivate some rural 'squire, and then you may live according to your own taste you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I'll tell her at once to punish her for her cruel∣ty. [Aside.] Perhaps, sister, I may have it in my power to do so without captivating a rural 'squire—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I am glad to hear it; but we won't talk of your visionary schemes at present. (I won't let her explain herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: There is a gentleman, sister—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Well, well, keep him to yourself; I'll hear none of your love-secrets.
SP.STAGE: Enter a servant, and delivers a note to Mrs. Knightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: From my Lord Medway, madam; the servant waits for an answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Lord Medway! what can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: My compliments to his Lordship, and shall be glad of the Colonel's company. [Exit Serv.] You were go∣ing to say something of a gentleman, Clara, ha, ha, pray who is the gentleman? But before you tell me your secret, I'll inti∣tle myself to the favour by making you my confidant. I have made a conquest you must know, of which this billet informs me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: A conquest, sister! I thought this note had come from Lord Medway.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Why, so it does, and the conquest is, tho' not of Lord Medway, yet of one who I hope will be Lord Medway—I'll read you the note.

P.Q:
“'Tis sometimes as great a fault to be too modest as too bold; my son is charmed with you, yet durst not tell you so. I told him that I would, and even went so far as to promise him a favourable reception. You see, madam, my credit as
a man of sagacity is at stake on this occasion, and I am sure you have too much goodness to let me forfeit it. I flatter my∣self you will allow Colonel Medway the honour of kissing your hand. He will wait on you in half an hour if you do” not forbid him.

POSTSCRIPT.P: P. S. 'I hope you will be alone.'

SP.P: What do you say to this, Clara! Is your lover as pretty a fel∣low as Colonel Medway?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly,
SP.P: Oh, sister, this is too much! but I give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: What's the matter, child! Why surely, my dear Clara, thou couldst not have any design, upon the Colo∣nel! Could you suppose that a man of family like him would marry without a fortune to support his rank and title?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I am satisfied I was mistaken, madam, and shall now be obliged to you if you will send me into the country di∣rectly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Why really, my dear, I think you judge right. I am sorry you have been so imprudent as to suffer any little gallantries, with which the Colonel might have treat∣ed you, to take a serious hold on you; but since it has hap∣pened so unluckily, I own I think it will be rather aukward for you to be in the house on the occasion; for, to tell you the truth, I intend to marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Then, sister, I will, if you please, retire for the present, to the house of my friend who brought me up, till you are at leisure to dispose of me otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: You are perfectly right, my dear; I am pleased at this mark of your discretion—We don't part in an∣ger, Clara; I shall always be your sincere friend, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I hope so, sister—I will just go and give a few directions to the servant, and then come to take my leave of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P:
You will not then be long in giving your
orders, for I suppose you would not chuse to meet the Colo∣nel here. Besides, you find, he desires to see me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I shall not interrupt you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Poor Clara! I pity you, and am sorry to build my happiness on the ruin of your's; but I'll make you amends. I see she loves, but 'tis plain she is not beloved. Per∣haps 'tis really as I said, and he has won her affections by a few compliments, meant only in gaieté de coeur. I hope that may be the case; for, notwithstanding my tenderness for him, I have delicacy enough to be unhappy, if I did not wholly possess his heart.
SP.STAGE: Enter Maid, and gives Mrs Knightly a letter.
SP.P: Why, this is for my sister!

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Madam, you ordered they should all be brought to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh, I had forgot—It is of no great con∣sequence now; but let us see who this is from—George Medway! I am almost afraid to read it, but I will know the worst.

P.Q: “Within this hour, my Clara, the faithless despicable man, who called himself your lover, will supplicate your sister for her hand, and with a heart long devoted, and never, never to be recalled from you, offer mean, deceitful vows to her.' (Heaven's! what's this?) 'I know not what I write, for de∣spair dictates to my trembling hand. Hate me, despise me, I conjure' (I wish I could do so ) 'yet hear the reasons for this fatal change—” Oh, this has given me an a∣gue fit!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I am come now, sister, to bid you farewell.
SP.STAGE: (Mrs. Knightly rushes out of the room.
SP.P:
Bless me, what can be the matter with my sister! she seems
strangely agitated—she was reading a letter—it was not that which she just now shewed to me.—What can it be? but I'll not intrude to ask her; I believe she can dispense with the ceremony of an adieu, and I can depart without one.
SP.STAGE: [As she is going out, Colonel Medway is shewn in by a servant, both stop short, and look at each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I did not expect this, Clara! I thought you would have spared me the pangs of such a meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I was not designed, Sir, believe me; yet, if you had vouchsafed to have given me but a little notice of this visit, it would have been but kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I thought my letter, distracted as it was—would at least have prevented an interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: What letter!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Did not you receive one from me within this half hour? it was the earliest notice I could give you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: I received none; but now you mention it, I am afraid it has fallen into my sister's hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: If so, then, Clara, what a monster must I appear to you? ignorant as you are of the motives of my strange con∣duct, which in that letter I explained at full.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Indeed, I am but ill prepared for such a sud∣den shock—yet I am willing to believe you must have had strong reasons for what you have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Can the generosity of your heart admit it as an ex∣cuse for my leaving you, that it is to save from utter and immediate ruin, a father that I dearly love?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: It can, Sir, and honour you for the motive; for I am sure that nothing else could have brought about such an event; and I should little deserve that esteem which I hope you still retain for me, if I could not give up my seeble claim to your tenderness, for ties of so much more impor∣tance.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Oh Clara, why did I give you up? what have I got to compensate for your loss!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P:
Your virtue! the consciousness of having act∣ed right—You have broke no oaths, no promises to me; nay,
I have often told you I would never be your's but with your father's consent; for sunk as I am in fortune, I would not meanly creep into a family that rejected me. And for this reason, I would neither give, nor receive a vow; but left you at full liberty to make a better choice, when your duty or your interest should urge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: That last word, madam, carries a reproach in it, which I cannot bear from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Do not mistake me, Sir; I have not the least suspicion, that interest has the smallest share in this action—I wish it had—for then perhaps I should part with you with less reluctance, than now I own I have power to do—but we must not touch upon this string—My sister loves you, and I hope will make you happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Happy do you say! no, Clara, no, happiness and I have shaken hands; what I have done to-day has made a wretch of me for life.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Oh Sir—shew more indifference, if you would not have me repine too much, at my own sad fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: And what is mine then, Clara, condemned to losing what is dearer to me than life; with the superadded grief of giving up my days to one I cannot love.—Your condition is not quite so wretched; you still are free, and time may in∣cline you to bestow your heart upon some happy man.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Never, never.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Do not say so—I had but that hope left to keep me from desperation—If I lose it, I shall forget all obligati∣ons, and give my father up to poverty and shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: No more I beseech you, Sir—you have made a noble sacrifice of your love—do not lose the merit of your silial goodness, by repenting of an act, that raises you higher even in my esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Clara—the tears stand trembling in your eyes while you speak—pray give them vent, for I am ashamed to weep alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: See—mine are dispersed already—Collect yourself I beg of you, you have a noble character to sustain—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Oh Clara, I am unequal to the task—I have no for∣titude left—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Think on your unhappy father, Sir! let that keep up your resolution. I grant you have a difficult task, for my sister may possibly think herself affronted by the expla∣nation you have made in that letter, which has fallen into her hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I hope she may!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Nay, do not indulge in such a vain hope, 'tis but a surmise of mine, and may have nothing in it—I know she suspected our attachment to each other, yet that did not check the progress of her love.—I am going to quit her house directly, and this, Sir, for my own, for my sister's, and for your sake, is the last time we must ever meet—forget me, Sir, and try—I conjure you try to be happy—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Clara—stay—stay!—So! all's at an end—and the hope I had nourished for years is vanished like a dream.—This trial was more than I thought I could sup∣port; but her noble firmness, I believe, made me ashamed to sink quite under the blow that has parted us for ever—I wish I were out of this fatal house—for I am very unfit to act the lover's part.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: How now, Medway! what is the meaning of this? alone, and with a countenance of despair! I bid you wear a better face. Where's Mrs. Knightly? have you not seen her yet? I thought, by this time, to have found you at her feet, and as I passed by the door, stepped in to help you to make love; for I know your heart is not warm in the business.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord I am very glad you are come; you must, indeed, make love for me; for I assure you I am in no condi∣tion to speak for myself

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter, man? I suppose Miss Richly and you have been whining over one another; did not I warn you against that, George, and bid you write to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: So I did, my Lord; but unfortunately she did not re∣ceive my letter; so that by accident we met just now, not, I assure you, with the least design on either side.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That was unlucky; but how came she to miss of your letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: By a circumstance still more unlucky, for she is afraid her sister got it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What a curst untoward accident, if that be so! yet her love for you will make her overlook all this. 'Twas but a thing of course, mere gallantry.—I'll lead you to her, and turn it off.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I beg of you, my Lord, to see her first alone; she does not yet know that I am come; the servant conducted me to this room, supposing she was here, and lucky was it for me that it happened otherwise; her sister's presence so disconcert∣ed me, that I should have acquitted myself but very ill to∣wards her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But she expects you by this time; a lover and out∣stay his appointment! for shame, George!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Let me beseech your Lordship to dispense with my seeing her just now; I'll take a turn or two in the Park, and endeavour to compose myself; and if my passion for her sister should be mentioned, you, my Lord, can, with a better grace than I, give it what turn you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Well—perhaps it may be better so. I own I had rather she should speak of that to me than to you: get you gone quickly—I'll prepare the way for you—She admits me to her toilet.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Lord Medway's House.
DIV3.P:
BY what a strange fatality are all my actions governed!—Nothing that I can devise but what ends in disap∣pointment and vexation.—Yet in this last instance, I ought to be thankful for my disappointment; for had my design
been accomplished, into what a horrid gulph should I have plunged my children. It makes my blood run cold to think of it.—I was born for destruction, and the ruins I have made myself are now come tumbling on my head. No hope left for avoiding them—no prospect before me but disgrace.—And the life of shame I have to look back on! To think how I have abused and perverted every gift bestowed on me for a blessing! How I sicken at my own reflections—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, I have been endeavouring to assume such a frame of mind, as will, I hope, enable me to go through with the task in which I have engaged. I am ready now to wait on Mrs. Knightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I—did not expect you back so soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I thought, my Lord, the sooner I returned, it would be the more agreeable to you, as well as respectful to the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Can you feel nothing more than respect for that la∣dy, son?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, you know I cannot. My heart is given to another. I must be unhappy, yet I hope I shall not make Mrs. Knightly so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Poor woman—she is already too much so.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Have you had any conversation with her, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I have.—You cannot be her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I am willing, my Lord, if the lady will accept of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You know not what you say—Oh, George, George—you will start when I tell you the strange discovery I have made.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: What is it, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Mrs. Knightly—she to whom I would have join∣ed you—I find is—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh Medway!—my own daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You amaze me, my Lord—how did you discover it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
When I went to sollicit for you, I found her in her
closet, under great agitation, on account of the letter you had written to her sister.—I pleaded for you, but found her a∣verse and cold.—In a little pause of discourse, I happened to cast my eyes on the picture of a lady, which hung just before me, and was struck with the resemblance of a beauty whom, in my early days, I loved, and cruelly betrayed.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I remember, my Lord, to have heard you speak of some such thing—a lady, who, when you made your first campaign in Portugal, gave you her love.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: The same—I thought the injured countenance seem∣ed to frown upon me. Surprized at the sight, I hastily de∣manded whose the picture was, and was told by Mrs. Knight∣ly 'twas her mother's.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: That must, indeed, my Lord, have shocked you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, 'twas nothing to what I suffered after, when farther urging her to satisfy my curiosity, she told me her mother's name and family! The apparent confusion this threw me into, rouzed her in her turn to ask me some que∣stions, which brought about this amazing explanation.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: She could not know you by your name, my Lord, as it was since my birth you assumed that with the title of Med∣way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: True.—She had heard of me by my own family name, and asked me, with a faultering voice, whether I had not formerly been at Lisbon, and borne the name of Selby. My acknowledging that I had, threw her into agonies, from which I, with difficulty, recovered her.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Did you never know, my Lord, that you had a daugh∣ter by that Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh no, no! I was recalled to England early in my amour with her. I married soon after my return, and, thoughtless and young as I then was, never enquired after her more.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: How then, my Lord, can you be certain of this fact?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, Medway! by too sure an evidence—The pe∣nitence and deep remorse of a dying woman! The unhappy lady confessed the secret, with all its circumstances, to this her daughter, when she was on her death-bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Mrs. Knightly, then, had passed for Mr. Richly's daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: She had; the match between him and her mother was hastily concluded by her friends, immediately after my departure. At the time of this lady's birth, Mr. Richly was absent on his affairs in the Indies; and tho' she came into the world in less than seven months after the marriage, yet (this circumstance being carefully concealed from him) he never doubted of her being his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Poor Clara! she then has been doubly wronged, in being deprived of her birth-right, as well as in losing the un∣equal portion which her father left her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That was the cause which wrung the secret from her dying mother's breast. Her deceased husband had, through a partial fondness for his supposed eldest daughter, left her such a disproportionate share of his wealth; and the mother, in divulging the secret, charged Mrs. Knightly, with her last breath, to do justice to her sister. This she herself, in the hurry of her shame, surprize, and grief, acknowledged to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I long to know, my Lord, what resulted from this ex∣traordinary interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Mrs. Knightly's agitations are not to be described. She wept and wrung her hands. I mixed my tears with her's; and, while she fell on her knees before me, I involuntarily dropped on one of mine, and begged of her to accept a bles∣sing from her repentant father. She strained me to her bo∣som; then rising with a noble air, she made a sorrowful and silent motion with her hand that I should leave her. I did so; and hastened home, to brood over my own reflections—Oh such reflections! such reflections, George!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My Lord, there is something so extraordinary in this event, that it looks as if Providence itself had interposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, Medway, 'tis for your sake then; I do not de∣serve the care of heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I beg, my Lord, you will not entertain such despond∣ing thoughts, but hope the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
George! there's no foundation here for hope; I
want that within which should support me. It is not the flashiness of wit, or vanity of superior talents, that can avail me in an hour like this. I'd give them all, nay, the whole world, were I master of it, to be possessed of such a virtuous self-acquitted heart as yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Your thinking thus, my Lord, makes you almost the very man you wish to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
