SP.P: Oh, George, George! words cannot describe the anguish which I feel. I should be resigned to it, did it con∣cern myself only, as the just punishment of a life of folly and vice; but when I think of you and of your mother, I am di∣stracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My dear! [Lord Medway turns from her.] Medway, why do you let your father sink thus under his apprehensions?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Do you speak to him, madam, he wants your tender∣ness to sooth the troubles of his mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My dear, you have no cause to be thus affected; I come a happy messenger of joyful news to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Joyful, do you say! that would, indeed, surprise me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Mrs Knightly is in my chamber, my Lord. We have had a long conversation. She has told me the strange event which this day has unfolded, and begs to speak with you—shall I bring her in?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Ay, pray do, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Reassume your spirits, my Lord; I dare promise you a happy issue to this affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I own this unexpected visit from Mrs. Knightly has a little revived me; and the generous frankness with which she has communicated the secret to my wife, shews she has a noble and enlarged mind.
SP.STAGE: Enter Lady Medway and Mrs. Knightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: My Lord, I thought to have found you a∣lone. I cannot, without confusion, look up to Col. Medway.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You, madam, have no cause; but, if my son's pre∣sence creates in you any uneasiness, he shall withdraw.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: He need not, my Lord; for as he is mate∣rially concerned in what I have to say, 'tis fit he should be pre∣sent at my explanation. I presume, sir, you are by this time no stranger to my story.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I think myself happy, madam, in finding I have so near and tender a claim to your regard.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I hope to give you one still nearer, sir. I will not now apologize for the means by which I came at the knowledge of that mutual love which I find there is between my sister and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: It needs no excuse, madam; it was a happy event, as it gave my Lord the opportunity of making a discovery so fortunate for us all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: My Lord, I owe my sister a large amends for the distress I have occasioned her on more accounts than one, and you in your turn, I think should recompense your son for the sacrifice he was willing to make to you. Has he your permission to make Clara his bride?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Oh, madam, you are too, too good.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: You have but little reason, sir, to say so yet. My Lord, the Colonel's love for my sister ensures his happiness, and, to render her acceptable to you, I am ready to share half my fortune with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, Medway, what an exalted mind is here!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My dear, do not keep your son suspended; he seems to check the transports that I see rising in his heart, till he has his father's sanction to his love.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Take, take your Clara from this excellent creature's hand, and may you both be blessed!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: No thanks, Colonel—[the Colonel advances to Mrs. Knightly.]—restrain your raptures till you see my si∣ster. I have sent to desire her company here—And now, my Lord, I hope I have, by this one act of justice (for it is no more) made happy, the nearest, and dearest relations I have on earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Son! Lady Medway! help me to praise and to ac∣knowlege as I ought, such unexampled goodness!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh, my dear, I want words—Medway's gra∣titude, you see, has stopt his utterance.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Miss Richly, madam, is below.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: My Lord, and Lady Medway, will you let me have the pleasure of presenting the Colonel to my sister without any other witness?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord and Lady.
SP.P: By all means.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You, madam, have the best right to dispose of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Come, sir.
SP.STAGE: [She gives him her hand, and he leads her out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, Lady Medway, I have not merited the benefits which are thus showered down upon me—But it is your good∣ness, your's and my children's virtue, have been the care of Providence, and I am blessed but for your sakes. Yet, my dear, I have the satisfaction to assure you, that what has pas∣sed this morning, joined to some other late incidents, have so thoroughly awakened reflection in me, that from this day for∣ward you will find me a new man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Lord, if you are sensible of any thing in your con∣duct that you would wish to rectify, I rejoice that you have taken your resolutions from the feelings of your own heart; for it would grieve me if I thought I had even by a look re∣proached you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You never did, madam; I acknowledge you have been the best of wives; 'tis time now that I should in my turn study to deserve that constant and tender regard from you, which I have hitherto but too much slighted. And now, best of women, receive my hand a second time; and with it an as∣surance, which I could never make before, that you possess my heart entire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh, my dear, I never was truly happy till this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You'll find my conduct as perfectly reformed as your heart can wish; assure yourself you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Pray, my dear, no more—you are now every thing that I would have you to be. I have but one wish left, which,
could it be accomplished, would render me completely happy—Poor Louisa!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I understand you, my dear—I hear young Bran∣ville is returned.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: He is, my Lord; he arrived last night—I do not presume to mention him; but indeed she cannot be happy with Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I would willingly gratify you in every thing; but how can I acquit myself with honour to Sir Anthony? You know he has my promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I know it, my dear; yet am I sure he is still so much in Mrs. Knightly's power, that with her assistance, I make no doubt but you could be easily disengaged from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: If that could be done—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: We shall certainly have a visit from him presently; suppose, my Lord, Mrs. Knightly were to try her influence on him when they meet, it will be a good opportunity—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Well, my dear,—you shall take your own way.
SP.STAGE: Enter Colonel Medway, Mrs. Knightly, Miss Richly, and Louisa; while Lord Medway and the Colonel talk apart.
(Mrs. Knightly presents her sister to Lady Medway.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Madam, receive a sister from my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Richly.
SP.P: Oh, sister, my obligations to you—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: No more, sister; I have but acquitted my∣self of a duty—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Louisa, I have been petitioning for you once more; my Lord has yielded, if he can with honour get off from his word to Sir Anthony. Dear Mrs. Knightly, with a little of your help, I am sure it could easily be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Madam, you may command me in any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Oh, madam, a word from you, nay a kind look, would I am sure recal your fugitive lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly
SP.P: I have not the vanity to think so; but since it will be agreeable to you, I'll try if I have still any interest in him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: This is about his time of visiting us. What if you were to make the experiment here'

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: To oblige you, ladies—thus much I must tell you, I never mean to marry again; but I know it will con∣tent Sir Anthony barely to be restored to my good graces.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir Anthony Branville is below, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I'll wait on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Dear my Lord, suffer him to be conducted in here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: My Lord, I have a design of stealing him from Miss Medway I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh I see you have been plotting—Desire Sir Anthony to walk up—Louisa, on this joyful day I must not suffer you to wear a look of discontent—You owe all to this lady, and the best of mothers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Louisa, you had best retire.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Anthony, bows low to Lord and Lady Medway, then looks round with surprise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, I thought my eyes would have been blessed with the sight of my fair mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Then I find it is all over. [Half aside.] What, Sir Anthony, not a look! Have you quite forgot me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Ah, madam, that enquiry comes a little of the latest, I do assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I am sorry for it, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, I hope your Lordship is of opinion that I do not deviate from that fidelity which I owe your excellent daughter, in entering into conference with this lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: By no means, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I flatter myself I am indulged with your ladyship's favourable construction on the same occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Without doubt, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Colonel, I would entreat the favour of being un∣censured by you likewise.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Oh, Sir Anthony, the laws of good breeding are not to be dispensed with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, I am glad of the opportunity of asking your pardon, in presence of this worthy family, for any part of my behaviour which you may have taken amiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, I am not worthy of so preat a concession; would to heaven there had never been any occasion given for it!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I wish so too, Sir Anthony; but I find my repentance comes too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Repentance! heavens, madam, do you conde∣scend to feel any compunction on the occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I do indeed, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Then, madam, I apprehend it will not be so ad∣viseable for me to abide within the reach of your influence; I think I cannot do a wiser thing than to stop my ears against your ailurements.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Not till you have first heard me, dear Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Dear Sir Anthony! I had best depart, Lady Medway.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: No, pray stay, good Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: There is a great peril in it, I assure your lady∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I thought your love for my sister, Sir Anthony, would be a sufficient guard against your relapsing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth
SP.P: Her charms, Colonel, I am ready to acknowledge should be an armour of proof; but give me leave to tell you, if there be a vnlnerable part about me, this forceress (craving her pardon for the expression) will certainly find it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, I confess I have been to blame in triding with a man of your worth; yet I own I did not think you would have taken my little capricious coyness for an absolute refusal of your addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, madam, take care; I am but a man; though I hope not without fortitude to sustain those trials of my virtue and my patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: 'Tis l, Sir Anthony, who have most need of fortitude—but go, ungrateful as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Do you hear that, my Lord? Before heaven, there never was such an inchantress since the days of Armida.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am surprised, I confess, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Well you may, my Lord—she is hung round with spells—I do aver it to you I am rooted here; I have not power to stir, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Bless me, Sir Anthony, that's very strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I use the word but metaphori∣cally, Colonel; I have not absolutely lost the use of my limbs, thank heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then, Sir Anthony, you had better retire, before it be too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Ay do, and carry that love, which was my right, to Miss Medway; but let me tell you, Sir, as a punish∣ment for your inconstancy, that her heart is already given a∣way to another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: 'Tis unlawful in you, madam, to slander an in∣nocent lady's reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: I speak nothing but the truth, Sir Anthony; and what is more, I know your nephew Branville is the man, and that she is equally beloved by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My nephew Branville! oh heavens, madam, what do you tell me! my Lord! my lady Medway! may I believe what this incomprehensible fair one says?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, I must own that I believe there is an af∣fection between your nephew, and my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I am thunder-struck—petrified—converted in∣to stone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I think, Sir Anthony, there is nothing so extraordi∣nary in the circumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Madam, there is such a degree of impurity, in the bare imagination of a nuptial so circumstanced, as has, I assure you, totally subverted my whole system.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I am sorry, Sir Anthony, you were not informed of this sooner.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Sir, 'tis not too late to prevent my honour from being stained.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You must judge for yourself in this case, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lord, passionately as I admire the lady, I would suffer martyrdom, rather than solemnize a marriage under such inauspicious influence.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, you are not pressed to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Colonel, I am not a man of a sanguinary spirit, but if such a measure is deemed necessary—I am at your service either a foot or on horseback—you understand me.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: There is no occasion, I assure you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I am ready—that's all—my alacrity is pretty notorious on those occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: For my part I approve of your punctilio intirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I am proud of your approbation; my Lord, I hope I am honoured with yours, in giving up my pretensions to the fair lady, your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir, you have my free consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Then, Sir Anthony, I am sure you have too much generosity not to promote your nephew's happiness, if my Lord is willing.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I have no objection to Mr. Branville, madam,—but Sir Anthony knows my inability to give my daughter a for∣tune equal to her rank—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord, I am sure, Sir Anthony is too noble, to let the sordid consideration of money be a bar to the happiness of two faithful lovers—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: On the contrary, madam, I am charmed that my nephew has such an opportunity, of shewing the generosity in∣herent in the family of the Branvilles, by contemning riches, in comparison of beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir Anthony, he deserves all your affection; for though I know he doats on my sister, yet hearing that you addressed her, he resolved to give her up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: Generous young man!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Ah ladies, see what delight the little sportive god takes in persecuting us true lovers!—My Lord, if my ne∣phew has your consent, I assure you I will render him in point of fortune, worthy of the lady of his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir, after an instance of such generosity, your alliance must be doubly acceptable to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: And now, Sir Anthony, I hope you will return to your lawful sovereign.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Arbitress of my fate, thus I reassume my happy bondage—
SP.STAGE: [He kneels and takes Mrs. Knightly's hand.
Enter Sir Harry and Lady Flutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: What the duce is all this! my uncle in heroics at my widow's feet! every thing's topsy-turvy I think—My Lord! Lady Medway! an explanation quickly, for hea∣ven's sake! Miss Medway gave us a hint of some strange things that were going forward here—What are you all about?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Dear Mrs. Knightly, I absolutely die with cu∣riosity!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: My dear, that's a disease that will never kill you, for you have been wonderfully subject to it ever since you and I were acquainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: Prithee, Sir Harry, let your tongue keep pace with your wit, and then you will not talk so fast.—Tell me, do, Mrs. Knightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: No, don't Mrs. Knightly—My dear, you real∣ly put me in mind of the cat in the fable, who was metamor∣phosed into a fine lady; but upon the first temptation—slap—egad she was a cat again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: And you put me in mind—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Take care, my dear, take care.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Beware of a relapse, lady Flutter, you are now happy if you are inclined to continue so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Flutter.
SP.P: So, my Lord! who has metamorphosed you, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Lady Medway.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Knightly.
SP.P: My dear lady Flufter, you shall know all at another opportunity. For the present, I am sure it will give you pleasure, to wish the Colonel and my sister joy on their happy union, to which my Lord has consented. You are to congratulate Miss Medway too on her approaching nuptials with Mr. Branville.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P:
And you are to felicitate me, niece Flutter, on
being permitted the transcendent happiness, of once more bask∣ing in the sunshine of this lady's favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And you are all to congratulate me, upon a double occasion; first, on that of being perfectly blessed in domestick joys; and next, that of seeing me a thoroughly reformed man.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: WHAT strange odd maggots fill an author's pate?
A female court of justice—rare conceit!
Ladies, I give you joy of your new stations,
I think you've had a trial—of your patience.
What, five long acts, and not one pleasant sally!
But grave Sir Anthony's attempt to rally—
No sprightly rendezvous, no pretty fellows,
No wife intriguing, nor no husband jealous!
If to such innovations you submit,
And swallow tame morality for wit:
If such dull rules you let a woman teach,
Her next attempt, perhaps, will be to—preach.
I told her (for it vexed me to the heart).
Madam—excuse me—I don't like my part—
'Tis out of nature—never drawn from life,
Who ever heard of such a passive wife?
To bear so much—'tis not in flesh and blood—
Such females might have liv'd before the flood.
But now the character will seem so flat,
Give me threats, tears, hysterics, and all that—
If this dont work upon my Lord, I hope
You'll so contrive the plot—I may elope.
Take my advice, I think I know the town,
Without such aids your piece will scarce go down.
Hold, friend, she cry'd—I think I've hit the way
To reconcile both sexes to the play;
For, while the prologue bids our own be sov'reign,
The scenes instruct the other how to govern.
A harmless plot—with credit to dismiss
The piece—you know the Ladies never hiss.
And tho' they should condemn it, yet the men sure
Will leave a woman's faults to women's censure.
They, prone to meekness, charity, and love,
Are always silent where they can't approve.
But if to loud applause we dare to aim,
It is the men must ratify our claim.
